{{Infobox person | name = Elizabeth Warder Crozer Campbell | other_names = Elizabeth Campbell, Elizabeth Warder Crozer, Betty Campbell | birth_name = Elizabeth Warder Crozer | birth_date = {{birth date|1893|8|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = Beach Haven, New Jersey, USA | death_date = {{Death date and age|1971|12|21|1893|8|11}} | death_place = [[Twentynine Palms, California]] | resting_place = Twentynine Palms Cemetery | nationality = American | known_for = Development of [[Environmental Archaeology]] techniques and establishing the presence of man in [[Pleistocene]] California deserts. | occupation = [[Archaeologist]] | spouse = William Henry Campbell, Joe Cecil Turman }} '''Elizabeth Campbell''' (1893–1971) was an American archeologist, notable for proposing a much earlier date for the presence of man in the desert Southwest than was generally accepted. She worked with her husband William (Bill) Campbell and first proposed that artifacts found along the shores of [[Lake Mojave]] and other [[Pleistocene]] lakes and rivers of the desert West were contemporaneous with the presence of water. They showed that there were virtually no sites that were not associated with archaic water sources. They hypothesized that the geologic features associated with the artifacts could be used to date the period of human habitation. This is the first use of what has become known as [[environmental archaeology]].<ref name='warren2017'>{{cite book|last1=Warren|first1=Claude N.|author-link1=Claude Nelson Warren|last2=Schneider|first2=Joan S.|title=Purple Hummingbird: A Biography of Elizabeth Warder Crozer Campbell|date=2017|publisher=University of Utah Press|isbn=9781607815181}}</ref>
== Life ==
Elizabeth Crozer was the youngest of four daughters born to upper class parents: John Price Crozer II and Elizabeth Steger Warder Crozer of [[Upland, Pennsylvania]]. She was born on August 11, 1893 at the Crozer summer cottage in [[Beach Haven, New Jersey]].<ref name="warren2017"/>
Her father was the grandson of [[John Price Crozer]], founder of the Crozer textile mills and possessor of the Crozer fortune.<ref name="mcQueen1982">McQueen, David A. (1982) ''The Crozers of Upland 1723-1926'', Serendipity Wress, Wilmington, Deleware</ref> When the elder John Crozer died the younger John Crozer inherited the mills and formed a partnership with his father under the name: S. A. Crozer and Son. When S. A Crozer died in 1910 John inherited coal companies, an iron and steel company, shared of a railroad and farms.<ref name="warren2017"/> The Crozer family founded the [[Crozer Theological Seminary]], the [[Crozer Arboretum]], and the [[Crozer Quarterly]]. They also built the [[George K. Crozer Mansion]] and are the namesake of the [[Crozer-Keystone Health System]].
Her uncle was [[Hermann Volrath Hilprecht]], professor of Assyriology at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and a scholar of Near Eastern archaeology. He was involved in the excavations at the Near Eastern site of [[Nippur]]. Campbell described in her diary how her Aunt Sallie would travel with Hilprecht to Europe and how "..[s]he never let her loveliness interfere with anything. She climbed the pyramids with three Arabs to push and pull."<ref name="crozer1908">Crozer, Elizabeth W. (1908) Diary of Elizabeth Crozer. Manuscript on file in the Joshua Tree National Park archives, Twentynine Palms, California</ref>
Campbell was schooled at home by a French tutor until age fourteen.<ref name="JTNP">Elizabeth Campbell - Joshua Tree National Park (U.S. National Park Service), https://www.nps.gov/jotr/learn/historyculture/campbell.htm, Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> In the fall of 1909 she began attending Miss Irwin's School (later the Agnes Irwin School) and graduated in 1911. Until World War II the education of most daughters of Philadelphia high society who attended Miss Irwin's ended at the secondary level.<ref>Baltzell, Edward Digby, (1989) ''Philadelphia Gentlemen: The Making of a National Upper Class'', Transaction Publishers, New Jersey.</ref> This was Campbell's last formal education.
Campbell married William (Bill) Campbell in May 1920.<ref>Antevs, Ernst, (1945) "William Henry Campbell, 1895-1944", ''American Antiquity'', 10(4) pp 379-382.</ref> Bill had served in World War I and had been gassed two days before the armistice of November 11, 1918.<ref name='warren2017'/> Bill's lung damage due to exposure to mustard gas caused them to move to [[Los Angeles, California]] and later to the drier climes of [[Twentynine Palms, California|Twentynine Palms]] where they established a homestead.
When Campbell's father died in 1926 she inherited a trust<ref name="JTNP"/> that enabled her and Bill to live comfortably for the rest of their lives. The Campbells were considered pillars of the Twentynine Palms community and developed a reputation as benefactors of both individual and community endeavours.<ref>Epstein, Joseph, "The Late, Great American WASP", ''Wall Street Journal'', December 21–22, 2013: C1-C2</ref><ref name="bagley1978">Bagley, Hellen, 1978) ''Sand in My Shoe: Homestead Days in Twentynine Palms'', Homestead Publishers, Twentynine Palms, California.</ref>
The Campbells maintained their residence in Twentynine Palms, and lived in a summer home on the shores of [[Lake Tahoe]], near [[Glenbrook, Nevada]]. It was here that Bill died in June 1944. After Bill's death Campbell sold the house in Twentynine Palms and moved to [[Carson City, Nevada]] where she met and married Joe Cecil Turman. The marriage lasted a short time before it was annulled.<ref name="warren2017"/> She moved to [[Tucson, Arizona]] around 1952 where she lived until 1961.
While living in Tucson she became a research associate with the [[Arizona State Museum]]<ref name="warren2017"/> and continued to work on the collections she and Bill had assembled over the years. In 1957 she had Arizona State Museum exhibit designer Robert Baker design a laboratory on the second floor of her Tucson home.<ref name="baker1957">Baker, Robert G, (1957) Drawing of a plan for archaeological laboratory for Tucson home of Elizabeth W.C. Campbell. Elizabeth Crozer Campbell file, Administrative Records, Arizona State Museum Archives, University of Arizona, Tucson (File 129A)</ref> During this time she also wrote a memoir about homesteading in Twentynine Palms, ''The Desert was Home.''<ref name="campbell1961">Campbell, Elizabeth W. Crozer, (1961) ''The Desert Was Home'', Westernlore Press, Los Angeles, California.</ref> Campbell made a trip to Twentynine Palms for an event marking the publication of her book and made the decision to move back there. She remained in Twentynine Palms for the rest of her life.<ref name="bagley1978"/> Elizabeth Campbell died on December 21, 1971. She was cremated and her cremains were interred alongside those of her husband Bill in a single plot in Twentynine Palms Cemetery.<ref>Elizabeth Warder "Betty" Crozer Campbell - Find a Grave Memorial, https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=92706255, accessed April 20, 2017</ref> Her obituary was published in ''The Masterkey.''<ref>(1972) Obit for Elizabeth Crozer Campbell, ''The Masterkey'' Vol. 46, No. 1</ref>
== Career in Archaeology ==
Campbell developed an interest in archaeology after she and Bill moved to Twentynine Palms. She began collecting arrowheads from nearby sand dunes while gathering firewood. When Bill McHaney, an old prospector who often visited their camp, told stories about Indian culture and caches of pottery, she listened and took notes.<ref name="JTNP"/> They would drive their trusty automobile -- "The Ship of the Desert"<ref name='campbell1961'/>—into the surrounding countryside looking for archaeological sites and visiting locations that McHaney told them about. It was said that archaeology met Campbell's need for "intellectual effort and accomplishment" and ameliorated the lonely desert life.<ref name='bagley1978'/> The Campbells were among the earliest archaeologists in the California desert. At the time (1925) virtually nothing was known about how long humans had lived in the deserts and the use of [[stratigraphy (archaeology)|stratigraphy]] as a means of chronological ordering of archaeological assemblages was just beginning.<ref name='warren2017'/>
Campbell's first monograph was published by the [[Southwest Museum of the American Indian|Southwest Museum]] in 1931.<ref name="crozer1931a">Campbell, Elizabeth Crozer, (1931) ''An Archaeological Reconnaissance of the Twenty Nine Palms Region'', Southwest Museum Papers No. 7, Southwest Museum, Pasadena, California.</ref> In 1932 the Campbells were appointed fellows in archaeology of the Southwest Museum and hosted a conference in Twentynine Palms on April 22–23 of that year.<ref name="hinchman1932">Hinchman, Fred K, (1932) "Southwestern Archaeological Federation at Twenty-Nine Palms.", ''The Masterkey'', 6(2):52-56</ref>
In 1933 the Campbells began their investigation of [[Pinto Basin]]. The area is associated with an extinct river channel and a dry lake bed.<ref name="campbellAmsden1934">Campbell, Elizabeth Crozer and Charles Amsden, (1934) "The Eagle Mountain Site.", ''The Masterkey'', 8(6):170-173</ref><ref name="CampbellCampbell1935">Campbell, Elizabeth W. Crozer and William Campbell, (1935) ''The Pinto Basin Site: An Ancient Aboriginal Camping Ground in the California Desert'', Southwest Museum Papers No. 9, Southwest Museum, Los Angeles, California.</ref> Campbell began consulting with geologists and paleontologists at the [[California Institute of Technology]]. Geologist David Scharf authored the geological chapter of the Pinto Basin report in one of the first collaborations of geologists and archaeologists. The artifacts from Pinto Basin were associated with the dry stream channel known as [[Pinto Wash]] and the lake bed known as [[Palen Dry Lake]]. This suggested that these sites were occupied during the period of time when the desert was considerably wetter.<ref name="warren2017"/> The Campbells argued that this wet period was not recent and presented as evidence the ground-water level being 97 feet below the surface of the surrounding arid mountain ranges. Starting with the Pinto Basin report, and for all research after, Campbell collaborated and consulted with well-known professionals in the fields of geology, paleontology, and archaeology. This increased her professional status and standing with the archaeological community.<ref name="warren2017"/>
In early 1934 the Campbells collected artifacts from the high shorelines of [[Silver Lake (Mojave)|Silver Lake]] playa (the northern basin of Lake Mojave) and in 1935 they collected from the shorelines of [[Soda Lake (San Bernardino County)|Soda Lake]] playa (the southern basin of Lake Mojave). Campbell stated she and Bill wanted to become experts in [[Dry Lake|playa]] culture.<ref name="campbell1935">Typewritten report from Elizabeth Campbell to the National Park Service on 1935 reconnaissance carried out in San Bernardino County. On file in the Joshua Tree National Park archives., Twentynine Palms, California</ref> Campbell believed that most ancient sites would be located in the [[Great Basin]].<ref name="campbell1937">Typewritten report from Elizabeth Campbell to the National Park Service on 1937 reconnaissance carried out in San Bernardino County. On file in the Joshua Tree National Park archives., Twentynine Palms, California</ref>
In 1936 Campbell published her seminal paper "Archaeological Problems in the Southern California Deserts"<ref name="campbell1936a">Campbell, Elizabeth W. Crozer, (1936) Archaeological Problems in the Southern California Deserts, ''American Antiquity'', 1(4) pp 235-300</ref> in which she outlined her hypothesis that associated prehistoric peoples with certain landforms. She believed a thorough study of the spatial relationships of artifact assemblages to the landscape would illuminate their chronology.<ref name="warren2017"/> This approach is clearly laid out in the Lake Mohave report<ref name="campbellCampbell1937">Campbell, Elizabeth W.C., William H. Campbell, Ernst Anteves, Charles E. Amsden, J.A. Barbieri and F.D. Bode, (1937) "The Lake Mohave Site" in ''The Archaeology of Pleistocene Lake Mohave: A Symposium'', Southwest Museum Papers No. 11:9, Southwest Museum, Los Angeles, California</ref> where she wrote: {{quote|text=In order to prove that a site has great age, it should be a pure site; that is, the artifacts should represent one period only, and it should be situated where the geology of the regions points to antiquity. For this reason we have sought man's ancient remains along extinct river channels and about the strand lines of playas and fossil lakes, indicated as such by beaches, terraces, spits, and wave-cut cliffs -- mute testimony to a past day of moister climate. We have not be disappointed in our search for locations by geological indication, for during the last two years the Desert Laboratory of the Southwest Museum has found and studied ten sites of the desired type. As all of these are now far from water, their occupants no doubt belonged to a period of greater rainfall.}}
Noted archaeologists of the day disagreed with Campbell's interpretation<ref name="rogers1939">Rogers, Malcom J, (1939) Early Lithic Industries of the Lower Basin of the Colorado River and Adjacent Desert Areas. ''San Diego Museum Papers 3'', San Diego Museum of Man, San Diego, California</ref><ref name="roberts1940">Roberts, Frank H.H Jr., (1940) Developments in the Problem of the North American Paleo-Indian. In ''Essays in Historical Anthropology in North America, Smighsonian Miscellaneous Collections'', 100:51-116, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.</ref><ref name="strong1941">Strong, William Duncan, (1941) Review of Malcom J. Rogers' ''Early Lithic Industries of the Lower Basin of the Colorado River and Adjacent Desert Areas''. ''American Anthropologist'', 43(3):453-455</ref> and this rejection of her hypothesis continued into the 1950s.<ref name="wormington1949">Wormington, H. Marie, (1957) ''Ancient Man in North America''. 4th edition, revisied. Originally published 1949, Denver Museum of Natural History, Denver, Colorado</ref><ref name="heizerwhipple1951">Heizer, Robert F. and M. A. Whipple (eds), (1951) ''The California Indians: A Source Book', University of California Press, Berkley and Los Angeles.</ref><ref>Heizer, Robert F, (1952) A Review of Problems in the Antiquity of Man in California. In "Symposium on the Antiquity of Man in California", ''University of California Archaeological Survey Reports'' 16:3-17, Berkley California</ref> [[Malcolm Jennings Rogers|Malcolm Rogers]]' report contained a number of factual errors that were not recognized until the 1950s and 60s.<ref name="brainerd1953">Brainerd, George W, (1953) A Re-examination of the Dating Evidence for the Lake Mojave Artifact Assemblage, ''American Antiquity'' 18(3):270-271</ref><ref name="warren1970">Warren, Claude (1970), Time and Topography: Elizabeth W.C. Campbell's Approach to California Desert Prehistory. ''The Masterkey'', 44(1):5-14</ref>
== Legacy ==
Archaeologists continue to study the Campbell collections house at [[Joshua Tree National Park]] and the [[Autry Museum]], and they continue to revisit the sites they visited, collected and studied.<ref name="oreWarren1971">Ore, H.T. and Claude N. Warren (1971) Late Pleistocene-Early Holocene Geomorphic History of Lake Mohave, California. ''Geological Society of America Bulletin'', 82:2553-2562</ref><ref name="owenEtAl2007">Owen, Lewis A., Jordan Bright, Robert C. Finkel, Manoj K. Jaiswal, Darrel S. Kaufman, Shannon Mahan, Ulrich Radtke, Joan S. Schnieder, Warren Sharp, Ashok K. Singavi, and Claude N. Warren (2007) Numerical dating of a Late Quaternary Spit-Shoreline Complex at the Northern End of Siver Lake Playa, Mojave Desert California: A Comparison of the Applicability of Radiocarbon, Luminescence, Terrestrial Cosmogenic Nuclide, Electron Spin Resonance, U-Series, and Amino Acid Racemization Methods. ''Quaternary International'', 166:87-110</ref><ref name="pendelton1970">Pendleton, Lorann S. (1979) Lithic Technology in Early Nevada Assemblages. Master's Thesis, California State University, Long Beach.</ref><ref name="warrenOre1978">Warren, Claude N. and H. T. Ore, (1978) Approach and Process of Dating Lake Mojave Artifacts, ''Journal of California Anthropology'' 5(2): 179-187</ref><ref name="warrenSchnieder2003">Warren, Claude N. and Joan S. Schneider (2003) On the Shores of Pleistocene Lake Mojave: Integrating the Data. ''Proceedings of the Society for California Archaeology'' 16:61-74</ref> Elizabeth Warder Crozer Campbell's contributions include:
* {{cite journal |last1=Campbell |first1= Elizabeth Warder Crozer |year=1931 |title=An Archaeological Reconnaissance of the Twentynine Palms Region |journal=Southwest Museum Papers |issue=7 |publisher=Southwest Museum |location=Pasadena, California }}
* {{cite journal |last1=Campbell |first1= Elizabeth Warder Crozer |last2=Campbell |first2=William |year=1935 |title=The Pinto Basin Site: An Ancient Aboriginal Camping Ground in the California Desert |journal=Southwest Museum Papers |issue=9 |publisher=Southwest Museum |location=Los Angeles, California }}
* {{cite journal |last1=Campbell |first1= Elizabeth W. Crozer |year=1936 |title=Archaeological Problems in the Southern California Deserts |journal=American Antiquity |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=295–300 |doi=10.2307/275244 }}
* {{cite conference |last1=Campbell |first1= Elizabeth Warder Crozer |last2=Campbell |first2=William H. |last3=Antevs |first3=Ernst |last4=Amsden |first4=Charles E. |last5=Barbieri |first5=J.A. |last6=Bode |first6=F.D. |year=1937 |title=The Lake Mohave Site. |conference=The Archaeology of Pleistocene Lake Mohave: A Symposium |journal=Southwestern Museum Papers |issue=11 |pages=9–44 |publisher=Southwest Museum |location=Los Angeles, California }}
* {{cite journal |last1=Campbell |first1=Elizabeth W. Crozer |date=1 April 1949 |title=Two Ancient Archeological Sites in the Great Basin |journal=Science |volume=109 |issue=2831 |pages=340 |doi=10.1126/science.109.2831.340|pmid=17838691|bibcode=1949Sci...109..340C }}

The '''Equestrian Monument of Cosimo I''' is a bronze equestrian statue erected in 1594 in the [[Piazza della Signoria]] in [[Florence]], region of [[Tuscany]], Italy. [[File:Statue Cosimo I Giambologna Piazza della Signoria n02.jpg|thumb|Monument of Cosimo I]] ==History== This statue follows the [[Ancient Rome|Classical Roman]] tradition of [[Equestrian statues]] as the monument to a ruler's power, evident from the [[Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius|Statue of Marcus Aurelius]] in ancient Rome and the [[Regisole]] in Ferrara, and continued in the Renaissance by examples such as [[Donatello]]'s [[Equestrian statue of Gattamelata|Statue of Gattamelata]] (1453) in Padua and [[Verrocchio]]'s [[Equestrian statue of Bartolomeo Colleoni|Statue of Bartolomeo Colleoni]] (1488) in Venice.
This monument was commissioned by Cosimo's son [[Ferdinando I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando I]] from the sculptor [[Giambologna]], who also completed the [[Rape of the Sabine Women (Giambologna)|Rape of the Sabines]] in the adjacent [[Loggia dei Lanzi]]. The Cosimo statue stands in front of the north corner of the [[Palazzo della Signoria]], the northernmost of the row of statues, adjacent to the [[Fountain of Neptune, Florence|Fountain of Neptune]] (1563) by [[Bartolomeo Ammannati|Ammannati]], that had been commissioned by Cosimo himself. Together this duo celebrates the land and sea ambitions of Cosimo. The base of the statue has reliefs with scenes from the life of Cosimo, including his coronation in Rome as Grand-Duke in 1570 and his entrance into Siena as a ruler (1557) after his victory over that republic.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bKseLWQBnsQC Viaggio per diverse parti d'Italia], (1832) Volume 3, page 183.</ref>
The posture of the trotting horse in this statue is similar to those of prior statues, with right leg raised, however unlike Marcus Aurelius, Cosimo uses stirrups and his horse shows the restraint of the bridle, albeit without much tension. Cosimo, like Gattemalata, holds a military baton, armor, and sheathed sword.
Some sources state the man and horse were cast separately, and the combined weight of the two was 23 thousand pounds.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FfATAAAAQAAJ Storia della scultura dal suo risorgimento in Italia], Volume 6, by Leopoldo Cicognara, page 402.</ref> A few decades hence, Ferdinando I would have his own [[Equestrian statue of Ferdinando I|Equestrian monument in Piazza dell'Annunziata]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9Ws5AAAAcAAJ Corografia dell'Italia], Volume 3, by Giovanni B. Rampoldi, 1837, page 1085.</ref>

{{other uses}} [[File:BadElster Schandfleck4549.JPG|thumb|right|[[Bad Elster]], [[Saxony]], [[Germany]] in April 2008. Wettiner Hof Hotel is awaiting renovation- locally it is known as the Schandfleck (the Eyesore).]] An '''eyesore''' is something that is largely considered to look unpleasant or ugly. Its technical usage is as an alternative perspective to the notion of [[landmark]]. Common examples include [[dilapidation|dilapidated]] [[buildings]], [[graffiti]], [[litter]], [[pollution|polluted areas]], and excessive commercial [[signage]] such as [[billboards]]. Some eyesores may be a matter of opinion such as controversial [[modern architecture]] (see also [[spite house]]), [[transmission tower]]s or [[wind turbines]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2006/jun/25/uk.renewableenergy|title=Homeowners get green light for 'eyesore' wind turbines|author=Nick Mathiason|date=June 25, 2006|publisher=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6763067.stm|title=Eyesore or gem: Gateshead car park |publisher=BBC|date= 18 June 2007 | first=Building | last=Site}}</ref> Natural eyesores include [[feces]], [[mud]] and [[weed]]s.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BL4Xrx-IFowC|page=255|title=Professional Planting Design|author=Scott C. Scarfone | isbn=978-0-471-76139-6 | year=2007 | publisher=John Wiley and Sons}}</ref>
==Effect on property values== In the USA, the [[National Association of Realtors]] says an eyesore can shave about 10% off the value of a nearby listing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dealing with an eyesore next door |url=http://realestate.msn.com/Selling/Article_mw.aspx?cp-documentid=5249535 |author=Rachel Koning Beals |accessdate=2008-03-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312214811/http://realestate.msn.com/Selling/Article_mw.aspx?cp-documentid=5249535 |archivedate=2008-03-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Remediation==
Clean-up programmes to improve or remove eyesores are often started by local bodies or even national governments. These are frequently called ''Operation Eyesore''.<ref>{{citation|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=February 9, 1972|title=British Start 'Operation Eyesore' Cleanup}}</ref> High-profile international events such as the [[Olympic Games]] usually trigger such activity.<ref>{{citation|publisher=New York Times|title=Russians Paint and Fuss As Olympic Games Near Putting Best Face on Things A Gleaming Soviet Capital Emigrate or Face Arrest|date=June 28, 1980|author=Craig R. Whitney}}</ref>
Others contend that it is best to nip such problems in the bud by addressing them while they are small, since signs of neglect encourage [[anti-social behaviour]] such as [[vandalism]] and [[fly-tipping]]. This strategy is known as ''[[Fixing Broken Windows|fixing broken windows]]''.
==Controversy==
Whether some constructions are eyesores is a matter of opinion which may change over time. [[Landmark]]s are often called eyesores.
===Examples of divided opinion=== [[File:Federation Square (SBS Building).jpg|thumb|right|[[Federation Square]] has divided opinion in [[Melbourne]].<ref name=Fed/>]] * [[Eiffel Tower]] – Upon its construction, Parisians wanted it torn down as an eyesore. Nowadays it is one of the world's top landmarks.<ref>{{citation| url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/news/eiffel-tower-still-worlds-top-landmark/2008/02/15/1202760546422.html |publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald |title=Eiffel Tower still world's top landmark |date=February 15, 2008}}</ref> * [[Golden Gate Bridge]] was controversial ahead of its construction, it being said in ''[[The Wasp (magazine)|The Wasp]]'' that it "would prove an eye-sore to those now living ... certainly mar if not utterly destroy the natural charm of the harbor famed throughout the world."<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v3WWvdOUcFEC&pg=PA278|page=278|title=Great American Bridges and Dams|author=Donald C. Jackson|isbn=978-0-471-14385-7|year=1988 | publisher=John Wiley and Sons}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.contempaesthetics.org/newvolume/pages/article.php?articleID=247|publisher=Contemporary Aesthetics|author=Yuriko Saito|title=Machines in the Ocean: The Aesthetics of Wind Farms}}</ref> It is now considered a notable landmark.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UcoiO0EgRRIC&pg=PA199|page=199|title=Frommer's San Francisco with Kids|author=Noelle Salmi|isbn=978-0-470-08017-7| year=2007 | publisher=Frommer's}}</ref> * [[Millennium Dome]] – the ugliest building in the world in a poll by the business magazine ''Forbes'' of "15 architects, all of whom were American apart from one who was British and one who was Canadian".<ref>{{citation|title=American architects vote the Millennium Dome 'the biggest eyesore in the world'|publisher=The Independent|author=Chris Gray|date=16 July 2002|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/american-architects-vote-the-millennium-dome-the-biggest-eyesore-in-the-world-648441.html | location=London}}</ref> * [[Federation Square]] – despite being hailed a landmark by many, it has equally been rejected by many notable Australians as an eyesore.<ref name=Fed>{{cite news | last=Murdoch | first=Scott | title=Costello slams Fed Square 'eyesore' | url= http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,20532581-2862,00.html| date=200-10-06 | work=Herald Sun | publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times Pty Ltd | accessdate=2009-05-29 }}</ref> * [[Wind farms]] – thought to be the worst eyesore by readers of ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'' but liked by others.<ref>{{citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/talking_point/3266673.stm|date=21 November 2003|title=What is the worst eyesore in the UK?|publisher=BBC}}</ref> * Boston's [[Government Center, Boston|Government Center]],<ref>{{citation|url=http://blastmagazine.com/the-news/2008/11/bostons-biggest-eyesore-city-hall-named-worlds-ugliest-building/|title=Boston’s biggest eyesore: City Hall named ‘World’s Ugliest Building’|author= Michael Corcoran|date=November 16, 2008 |accessdate=October 12, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303134902/http://blastmagazine.com/the-news/bostons-biggest-eyesore-city-hall-named-worlds-ugliest-building/|archivedate=March 3, 2012|work=Blast|deadurl=no}}</ref> where City Hall has been called "The World's Ugliest Building".<ref>{{citation|url=http://members.virtualtourist.com/vt/t/1c7/|title=The World’s Top 10 Ugliest Buildings|work=Virtual Tourist|accessdate=October 12, 2009}}</ref> * [[One Rincon Hill]] – Situated just south of [[San Francisco]]'s [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]], this high-rise condominium surrounded by shorter buildings has generated some mixed reviews. * [[Lloyd's building]] – Situated in the [[City of London]], this building was described as an [[oil refinery]] when it was opened in 1986<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.inlondonguide.co.uk/london-buildings/city/81-lloyds-building-insurance.html|title=The Lloyd's Building|accessdate=January 25, 2010}}</ref> for having most of its facilities, stairways and [[Air Conditioning|AC]] on the outside. Some people still say this, although the building has become more popular and liked in the recent years. * [[Tour Montparnasse]] - lone skyscraper in the [[Montparnasse]] area of [[Paris]], [[France]]. Its appearance mars the Paris urban landscape, and construction of skyscrapers have been banned in the city two years after its completion. A 2008 poll of editors on [[Virtualtourist]] voted the building the second ugliest building in the world. It is sometimes said that the view from the top is the most beautiful in Paris, because it is the only place from which the tower itself cannot be seen. * [[Brisbane Transit Centre]] and [[Riverside Expressway]] – have been called eyesores and planning debacles by [[University of Queensland]] Associate Professor of Architecture Peter Skinner.<ref name=BTC>{{cite news |first=Georgina |last=Robinson |title=Brisbane's biggest eyesores and planning debacles |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/articles/2008/01/24/1201025055483.html |work=Brisbane Times |publisher=Fairfax Digital |date=2008-01-24 |accessdate=May 29, 2009}}</ref> * [[Tricorn Centre]]. Built in 1964, it was initially highly respected.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3561069.stm | work=BBC News | title=R.I.P. Britain's Ugliest Building | date=March 24, 2004}}</ref>
===Structures that have been described as eyesores=== [[File:Spencer-street-power-station-melbourne.jpg|thumb|right|[[Spencer Street Power Station, Victoria|Spencer Street Power Station]]. Regarded for many years as Melbourne's worst eyesore, it was demolished in 2008.<ref name=SSPS/>]]{{Refimprove section|date=January 2018}} * [[Spencer Street Power Station, Victoria]] – an [[asbestos]] ridden landmark regarded by many as Melbourne's biggest eyesore.<ref name=SSPS>{{cite news |authors=[[Nick McKenzie]] and Cameron Houston |title=On the trail of a man of mystery |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/on-the-trail-of-a-man-of-mystery/2006/06/09/1149815316569.html?from=rss |work=The Age |publisher=Fairfax Digital |date=2006-06-10 |accessdate=May 29, 2009 | location=Melbourne}}</ref> It was demolished in 2008. * [[Cahill Expressway]] in [[Sydney]] – regarded by many as a major planning mistake.<ref name=CE>{{cite news|first=Doug |last=Conway |title=$1bn to demolish city's great eyesore |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23433182-5006784,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821042931/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23433182-5006784,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 21, 2008 |work=The Australian |publisher= |date= |accessdate=May 29, 2009 }}</ref> * [[Sydney Harbour Control Tower]] – constructed in 1974 and demolished in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/property/sydney-harbour-control-tower-headed-for-demolition/story-fn9656lz-1227305391801|title=Sydney Harbour Control Tower headed for demolition|work=[[The Australian]]|date=16 April 2015|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> * [[Riverside Plaza]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://minnesota.publicradio.org/collections/special/columns/news_cut/archive/2008/06/the_architecture_poll.shtml|title = The architecture poll|work = Minnesota Public Radio|last = Collins|first = Bob|date = June 13, 2000|accessdate = June 27, 2009}}</ref> * [[Embarcadero Freeway]] – Along [[The Embarcadero (San Francisco)|The Embarcadero]] in San Francisco, this double-decker elevated freeway blocked The Embarcadero's view and shadowed the boulevard under it. When it was demolished in 1991, the long-abandoned [[San Francisco Ferry Building|Ferry Building]] and the boulevard under the freeway were restored.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}<!-- source for claim that it was regarded as an eyesore, please --> * [[Petrobras Headquarters]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]], an ugly example of concrete brutalism applied to an office building.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.travelworth.com/die-before-you-visit-these-top-10-worlds-ugliest-structures.html|title = Die Before You Visit These Top 10 World’s Ugliest Structures|date = December 9, 2009|accessdate = July 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://english.cntv.cn/20120111/116985.shtml|title = Top 10 ugliest buildings in the world|accessdate = July 2, 2012}}</ref> * [[Hole in the Road|The Hole In The Road]] in [[Sheffield]], [[England]], filled in <!-- not a mistake-->in 1994.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}<!-- source for claim that it was regarded as an eyesore, please --> * [[City-Center]] in Helsinki, colloquially known as ''Makkaratalo'' (Sausage House) because of the concrete sausage-like railing circling the third floor parking lot. * [[Northampton Power Station]], England left derelict since 1975.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} * [[House of Soviets (Kaliningrad)|House of Soviets]], [[Kaliningrad]], [[Russia]]. "The ugliest building on Russian soil".{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} * School of Architecture, [[Royal Institute of Technology]], [[Stockholm]], Sweden. Won an opinion poll for Stockholm's ugliest building, by broad majority. Damaged by a fire in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=740&artikel=2435435 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120524132102/http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=740&artikel=2435435 |archivedate=2012-05-24 |df= }} </ref> * [[Spire of Dublin]] in [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland]] * [[American Dream Meadowlands]]. Most politicians and the public have equally criticized the building's appearance calling it "The ugliest building in [[New Jersey]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/nj_ugliest_building_fix_vfSvwNyiWghUjFmPYWbSiN|title=The ugliest building in New Jersey will get a new exterior, says Gov. Chris Christie|work=NYPOST.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/new_jersey&id=8032220|title=New Jersey Governor Christie promises facelift to NJ's 'ugliest' building |work= abclocal.go.com}}</ref> * [[Waldschlösschen Bridge]] in [[Dresden]], [[Germany]]. The [[Dresden Elbe Valley]] lost the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] status because of this bridge. * [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Widely regarded as a jarring and aesthetically unappealing addition to the local landscape.<ref>http://www.businessinsider.com/why-half-of-brooklyn-hates-the-new-barclays-center-stadium-2012-8</ref> * [[Cebu City|Cebu City Hall]], considered an eyesore by many during the early to mid 2000's, until it was renovated in 2007, and is now considered as one of the best city halls in the Philippines. * Majesty Building in [[Altamonte Springs]], [[Florida]] locally known as the I-4 Eyesore, a building that has been under construction since 2001.<ref>http://www.clickorlando.com/news/still-no-completion-date-for-i4-eyesore/22839816</ref> * [[Torre de Manila]], a high-rise development by [[DMCI Homes]] that dwarfs the [[Rizal Monument]].

{{Orphan|date=March 2012}}
'''Hilde Danielsen''' (born 1971) is a Norwegian social anthropologist and [[gender studies]] expert. She is editor-in-chief of [[Tidsskrift for kjønnsforskning]] (the Norwegian Journal of Gender Studies).<ref>[http://kilden.forskningsradet.no/c65969/artikkel/vis.html?tid=65971 Redaksjonen for Tidsskrift for kjønnsforskning] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120713170536/http://kilden.forskningsradet.no/c65969/artikkel/vis.html?tid=65971 |date=2012-07-13 }}, Kilden</ref> She is noted for her research on [[Housewife|housewives]].<ref>[http://bergenbibliotek.no/litteratur/tips-og-nytt/danielsen Husmorhistorier: Norske husmødre om menn, barn og arbeid]</ref><ref>[http://nyheter.uib.no/?modus=vis_bokmelding&id=91002134207 Husmorhistorier], På høyden 9.10.2002</ref><ref>Kristin Høiland, [http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article4236362.ece En moderne husmormiks], [[Aftenposten]] 24.sep. 2011</ref>
She has a [[cand.philol.]] degree from the [[University of Bergen]] in 1998 and a [[dr.art.]] degree from 2006. She has formerly worked for the [[Norwegian Museum of Hydropower and Industry]] and now works as a senior researcher at the [[Rokkan Centre]].
==Selected publications== * ''Dei moderne kvinnene i Odda : ein studie av mødrehygiene og barneavgrensing i mellomkrigstida'', Norwegian Museum of Hydropower and Industry, 2000, {{ISBN|82-90913-07-9}} *''Husmorhistorier'', Oslo, Spartacus, 2002, {{ISBN|9788243002074}} *''Med barn i byen : foreldreskap, plass og identitet'', University of Bergen, 2006, {{ISBN|82-308-0178-9}} *with Wencke Mühleisen, "Statens parkurs Godt Samliv", [[Tidsskrift for samfunnsforskning]], 1, 2009 *with Wencke Mühleisen, "Statens oppskrift på parseksualiteten", in Wencke Mühleisen and Åse Røthing (eds.), ''Norske seksualiteter'', Oslo, Cappelen, {{ISBN|978-82-02-29238-6}}
== References == <references />
==External links== *[http://rokkan.uni.no/people/?/$present&id=20 Hilde Danielsen], Rokkan Centre

{{Infobox organization |name = History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |abbreviation = HoMBRG |motto = |formation = {{Start date|1990}} |extinction = |type = Historical research body |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |leader_title3 = |leader_name3 = |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[Queen Mary University of London]] |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |website = {{Url|http://histmodbiomed.org/}} |former name = History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group }}
The '''History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group''' ('''HoMBRG''') is an academic organisation specialising in recording and publishing the [[oral history]] of twentieth and twenty-first century [[biomedicine]]. It was established in 1990 as the Wellcome Trust's '''History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group''',<ref name="MHL2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalheritage.org/2013/03/13/the-mhl-welcomes-a-new-content-contributor-2/|title=The MHL Welcomes a New Content Contributor|date=13 March 2013|publisher=[[Medical Heritage Library]]|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref> and reconstituted in October 2010 as part of the School of History <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.qmul.ac.uk/research/research-centres|title=Research Centres - School of History|website=www.history.qmul.ac.uk|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref> at [[Queen Mary University of London]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Wellcome|title=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group celebrates 21 years of innovation|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2014}}</ref><ref>http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/hss/140113.htm</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Wellcome|title=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group celebrates 21 years of innovation|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2014/WTP057432.htm |publisher=[[Wellcome Trust]] |accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref>
== History == The project originated as The [[Wellcome Trust]]'s History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group, and later functioned as the Academic Unit of the Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine. It was originally established at the Royal College of Physicians in 1990 and comprised Sir [[Christopher Booth]] (the Harveian Librarian) and Professor [[Tilli Tansey]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Aronson|first1=Jeff |title=Wellcome witnesses to twentieth-century medicine |journal=Cambridge Journal Medical History |date=July 1998 |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=404–405 |pmc=1044055}}</ref> Its purpose was to devise ways of stimulating historians, scientists & clinicians to discuss, preserve and write the history of recent biomedicine. The Group's activities were originally overseen by a Programme Committee, which included professional historians of medicine, practising scientists and clinicians.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pickstone|first1=John V.|title=A brief history of medical history|url=http://www.history.ac.uk/makinghistory/resources/articles/history_of_medicine.html |publisher=Making History|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> From 2000–2010 it was a constituent part of the Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine at University College London. In October 2010 it moved to the School of History, Queen Mary’s University, London. In 2011 the Group received a Strategic Award from the Wellcome Trust to embark upon a new project, "Makers of Modern Biomedicine".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Society|first1=The Physiological|title=Hidden voices and human stories|url=https://www.physoc.org/news/2012/hidden-voices-and-human-stories |publisher=The Physiological Society|accessdate=29 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.wellcomelibrary.org/iii/encore/search/C__SHistory+of+Biomedicine+Research+Group.+__Orightresult;jsessionid=F0C74ABF559F644E711241B44A7FAD7E?lang=eng&suite=cobalt|title=Wellcome Library Encore -- History+of+Biomedicine+Research+Group.+|website=search.wellcomelibrary.org|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Culture24-2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/science-and-nature/medicine/art375045|title=Five-year, £1.4 million project to reveal "unsung heroes" of biomedicine|date=31 January 2012|work=Culture24|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://genmedhist.eshg.org/news-events/|title=News & Events|work=Genetics and Medicine Historical Network|publisher=[[Cardiff University]]|accessdate=6 May 2017 |quote=The History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group, based at Queen Mary, University of London, continue to build upon their work documenting the recent history of clinical genetics research and practice. }}</ref><ref name="UniOfSurrey">{{cite web|url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/features/pioneering-work-biomedicine-celebrated|title=Pioneering work in biomedicine celebrated|date=25 August 2015|publisher=[[University of Surrey]]|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref>
== Outputs ==
An archive of oral and written history, plus videoed interviews, has been compiled by the HoMBRG and consists of three projects: Witness Seminars, Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History and SAD at 30. All material and documentation related to the project is deposited with the Wellcome Library. The resultant publications are open access,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Medical Humanities|first1=Centre for|title=New Open Access Publication – The Development of Narrative Practices in Medicine c.1960–c.2000|url=http://centreformedicalhumanities.org/new-open-access-publication-the-development-of-narrative-practices-in-medicine-c-1960-c-2000/ |publisher=[[Durham University]] |accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and made freely available online via the HoMBRG website, a partnership with the Medical Heritage Library,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Library|first1=Medical History|title=The MHL Welcomes a New Content Contributor|url=http://www.medicalheritage.org/2013/03/the-mhl-welcomes-a-new-content-contributor-2/|website=Medical History Library|publisher=Medical History Library|accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and iTunes.<ref name="apple.com">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/itunes-u/todays-neuroscience-tomorrows/id557520467?mt=10|title=Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History - Professor Sir Peter Mansfield - Free Podcast by Queen Mary University of London on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
The topics covered by the archive fall broadly into five themes: [[clinical genetics]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Historical Network|first1=Genetics and Medicine|title=The History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group, based at Queen Mary, University of London, continue to build upon their work documenting the recent history of clinical genetics research and practice|url=http://www.genmedhist.info/news-and-events/|accessdate=31 May 2015|publisher=Cardiff University|ref=none}}</ref> [[neuroscience]], global health and [[infectious diseases]], [[medical technologies]] and ethics of research and practice.
Resources from the archive are online at The History of Modern Biomedicine Archive<ref>{{cite web|title=The History of Modern Biomedicine|url=http://histmodbiomed.org/article/projects |publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> and the internet archive<ref>https://archive.org/search.php?query=publisher%3A%22London%3A+The+History+of+Modern+Biomedicine+Research+Group+at+UCL%22</ref>
=== Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History ===
The Group's 'Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History' initiative (2006-2008) was funded by a Wellcome Trust Public Engagement grant. It recorded interviews on three themes, [[neuropharmacology]], [[psychiatry]]/[[neuropsychology]], and [[neuroimaging]], with twelve neuroscientists, including [[Geoffrey Burnstock]], [[Salvador Moncada]], [[Michael Rutter]] and [[Uta Frith]].<ref name="TNTH">{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/article/about-todays-neuroscience-tomorrows-history|title=About Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History|publisher=HoMBRG|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
=== The Witness Seminars ===
A series of [[witness seminar]]s began in 1993, with regular meetings being held, about four per year. These recorded the voices of those who have contributed, in diverse ways, to the development of modern [[biomedicine]], using oral history methodology. The aim is to make the series widely available for education, research and outreach purposes.<ref name=JonesEM>{{cite book|editor1-last=Jones|editor1-first=E.M.|editor2-last=Tansey|editor2-first=E.M.|title=Monoclonal Antibodies to Migraine: Witnesses to Modern Biomedicine, An A-Z|date=2014|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|location=London|isbn=978 0 90223 895 4|pages=223|ref=none|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://patient.info/forums/discuss/migraine-diagnosis-treatment-and-understanding-270038|title=Migraine: Diagnosis, Treatment and Understanding - Migraine - Patient|website=patient.info|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Jones2016">{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Emma M.|year=2016|title=A witness seminar on the history of the Human Gene Mapping Workshops|journal=Gene|volume=589|issue=2|pages=123–126|issn=0378-1119|doi=10.1016/j.gene.2016.02.030|pmc=4925380}}</ref><ref name="Messenger">{{cite web|url=https://waste-management-world.com/a/an-oral-history-of-waste-management-by-university-historians-in-london|title=An Oral History of Waste Management by University Historians in London|last=Messenger|first=Ben|date=15 January 2016|work=Waste Management World|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Tansey2016">{{cite journal|last1=Tansey|first1=T |first2=A. |last2=Wilkinson |first3=A. |last3=Yabsley |first4=A. |last4=Zarros |year=2016|title=Physiology at the heart of modern biomedicine: Evidence through oral testimonies|journal=Proceedings of the Physiological Society|publisher=[[The Physiological Society]]|volume=37}}</ref> The results are published online,<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 978-1-134-70170-4| last1 = McConville| first1 = Sean| last2 = Bryson| first2 = Anna| title = The Routledge Guide to Interviewing: Oral History, Social Enquiry and Investigation |year=2013 |page=149}}</ref> with most edited transcripts appearing within 18 months.<ref name=JonesEM/>
Witness Seminar participants have included [[Usama Abdulla]], [[Thomas Brown (medical physicist)|Thomas Brown]], Professor [[Dugald Cameron]], Professor [[Stuart Campbell (obstetrician)|Stuart Campbell]], [[John Fleming (physician)|John Fleming]], Professor [[John MacVicar]], Professor [[Peter N.T. Wells|Peter Wells]], Dr [[James Willocks]], Sir [[Douglas Black (physician)|Douglas Black]], Sir [[John Gray (physiologist)|John Gray]], Sir [[Raymond Hoffenberg]], Dr [[Sheila Howarth]], Professor [[Peter Lachmann]], Sir [[Patrick Nairne]], Professor Sir [[Stanley Peart]] and Dr [[Peter Williams (physician)|Peter Williams]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Young|first1=Jacy|title=New Neuroscience & Applied Psych History Resources|url=http://ahp.apps01.yorku.ca/?p=3136 |publisher=Advances in the History of Psychology|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref>
Each witness seminar is transcribed and published by HoMBRG.<ref>http://www.medicalheritage.org/2014/10/mhl-partner-history-of-modern-biomedicine-research-group-celebrates-21st-anniversary/</ref> Recent volumes have been edited by E M Jones, C Overy and E M Tansey. {{As of|May 2017}} there are 62 Volumes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/article/wellcome-witnesses-volumes |title= Wellcome Witnesses Volumes |publisher=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group |date= |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> Titles include ''The Development of Brain Banks'', ''Narrative Medicine''; ''Migraine''; ''The National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles'';<ref>{{cite web|last1=Social Research|first1=NatCen|title=The story of Natsal, the nation’s sex study|url=http://www.natcen.ac.uk/blog/the-story-of-natsal,-the-nation%E2%80%99s-sex-study |publisher=NatCen Social Research|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and ''The Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC)''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Study of Parents and Children|first1=Avon Longitudinal|title=Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/alspac/ |publisher=[[Bristol University]] |accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> The publication of these works are often referred to by specialists in their fields of medical practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ehospice.com/Default/tabid/10686/ArticleId/3528|title=History of palliative medicine in the UK|first=|last=International|website=www.ehospice.com|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
The first two volumes were reviewed in ''[[Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine]]'' in 1999, with the comment, "Few books are so intellectually stimulating or uplifting."<ref name="BlauJN">{{cite journal|last=Blau|first=J N|year=1999|title=Wellcome Witnesses to Twentieth Century Medicine, Vols 1 and 2|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|volume=92|pages=206–8}} <!--PMC1297150 --></ref> Reviewing the series in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]'' in 2002, medical historian [[Irvine Loudon]] wrote, "This is oral history at its best...all the volumes make compulsive reading...they are, primarily, important historical records<ref name="Loudon2002">{{cite journal|last=Loudon|first=I.|year=2002|title=Book: Wellcome Witnesses to Twentieth Century Medicine|journal=BMJ|volume=325|issue=7372|pages=1119a–1119|issn=0959-8138|doi=10.1136/bmj.325.7372.1119/a}}</ref>
In 2014 a seminar, chaired by Professor Sir Brian Follett, with [[Norman Rosenthal]] and [[Alfred Lewy]], entitled 'The Recent History of [[Seasonal Affective Disorder]] (SAD): 30 Years of SAD' was undertaken on the topic of Seasonal Affective Disorder.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Association|first1=SAD|title=Wellcome Trust Wtness Seminar:An Important New Publication|url=http://www.sada.org.uk/sada_get_news_item.php?action=show&id=34-3-News |publisher=SAD Association|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> This resulted in a number of podcasts,<ref name="apple.com"/> and Volume 51 of the Witness Seminar publications.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Overy|editor1-first=C|editor2-last=Tansey|editor2-first=E.M.|title=The Recent History Of Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)|date=2014|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|location=London|isbn=978 0 90223 897 8|url=http://ischronobiology.org/Joomla_1.5.26-Stable-Full_Package/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=109:the-recent-history-of-seasonal-affective-disorder&catid=45:books&Itemid=68|accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none|language=English}}</ref>
=== Clips and Conversations ===
In 2015 the Group began producing oral history interviews with notable scientists and clinicians. This material is made freely available on YouTube (in the case of video interviews) and the Group’s website, as are the transcripts of both audio and video interviews.<ref name="OHHEN">{{cite web|url=https://ohhen.wordpress.com/2017/01/29/makers-of-modern-biomedicine-testimonies-and-legacy/|title=Makers of Modern Biomedicine: Testimonies and Legacy|publisher=Oral History in Higher Education Network|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Wikidata ===
{{Wikidata property|P3885}}
As the HoMBRG project came to an end, a [[Wikimedian in Residence]] was engaged, to create [[Wikidata]] records for the publications and those people interviewed in them.<ref name="WiR">{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/blog/introducing-wikimedian-residence-mr-andy-mabbett|title=Introducing Wikimedian in Residence, Mr Andy Mabbett|date=2 May 2017|publisher=HoMBRG|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading ==
* Monoclonal Antibodies to Migraine: Witnesses to Modern Biomedicine, An A-Z Ed. E M Jones and E M Tansey 2014 {{ISBN|978 0 90223 895 4}} * The Recent History Of Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) Edited by C Overy and E M Tansey 2014 {{ISBN|978 0 90223 897 8}} * Project to reveal hidden pioneers of modern medicine, http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/hss/62665.html * Renowned medical historian joins Queen Mary, http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/hss/37291.html

page.title: Impact of farmers' markets on economies within the United States

revision.comment: fix cite errors (except one unresolvable missing URL), combine repeated references
revision.text:
{{About|the economic impact of farmers' markets in the U.S|the commercial enterprise|Farmers' market}}
[[Farmers' market]]s are markets in which producers sell directly to [[consumer]]s. While farmers' markets do not have a measurable impact on the [[economy of the United States|United States economy]] as a whole, many studies have found that farmers' markets impact [[U.S. state|state]] and [[municipality|municipal]] economies as well as [[vendor]]s, local [[business]]es, and [[consumer]]s. These impacts are measured using the IMPLAN Input-Output Model and the Sticky Economic Evaluation Device (SEED), in addition to other methods. The economic impacts that are most frequently measured include effects on the [[revenue]] and [[income]] of local growers and local businesses, the effects on job creation, and the effects on other [[economic sector|sectors]] of state and local economies. Some obstacles that may reduce impact or create negative economic effects include [[market saturation|over-saturation]], [[socioeconomics|socioeconomic barriers]], the [[opportunity cost]] of farmers' markets, and the projected unsustainable growth of farmers' markets in the [[United States]].
==Methodology== Researchers use different methods to calculate the economic impact of farmers' markets on [[economy|economies]] in the [[United States]]. The reason to include [[methodology|methodologies]] in this article is to demonstrate how impact is measured differently, which influences the findings and conclusions of the studies. The most common methods used are the IMPLAN Input-Output Model and the Sticky Economic Evaluation Device, which are mostly used to calculate the impact of farmers' markets on state, [[municipality|municipal]], and local [[economy|economies]].
===IMPLAN input-output model=== The IMPLAN input-output model is a quantitative economic [[software]], technique, or [[data]] that facilitates [[analysis]] of spending.<ref name=IMPLAN>{{cite web|title=IMPLAN|website=IMPLAN.com|url = http://www.implan.com|access-date=25 August 2018}}</ref> This analytic tool, created by the [[U.S. Forest Service]] and the [[University of Minnesota]], uses the [[Bureau of Economic Analysis|Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA)]] [[Input–output model|input-output]] criterion combined with other data to compile tables that identify [[cash flow]]s between different [[economic sector|sectors]] of the [[economy]]. IMPLAN methodology has been used in studies on Portland and [[Iowa]]n farmers' markets to calculate the economic impact by studying consumption-based transactions. It is also used to compute data supporting studies on the impact of farmers' markets on [[vendor]] [[revenue]].<ref name=IMPLAN />
===Sticky Economic Evaluation Device (SEED)=== Market Umbrella is a [[nonprofit organization]] that developed the Sticky Economic Evaluation Device (SEED), a tool that measures the economic impact of a [[market (place)|public market]] on neighboring businesses. SEED multiplies the annual [[revenue]] generated by [[consumer]]s of the [[market (economics)|market]] and abutting businesses by the multiplier. Specifically, the Regional Input-Output Modeling System II multiplier is used, which is generated by the BEA ([http://BEA.gov BEA]). The RIMS II multiplier measures how many dollars remain in the regional or local [[economy]]. "The greater the interaction each dollar has with the local economy, the larger the multiplier." This methodology also gathers information through [[survey methodology|customer-intercept surveys]] and head count tabulation in order to calculate the economic impact the market has on its [[region]]. Market Umbrella provides markets with access to their survey templates and facilitates report generating through the use of online accounts on their website. The [[sales taxes in the United States|sales tax]] revenue generated by market consumers, including purchases at neighboring businesses, is additionally captured. The SEED methodology, developed with farmers' markets in mind, has been used to measure the economic impact of Crescent City Farmers' Markets.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is SEED?|url=http://www.marketumbrella.org/index.php?page=seed-learn}}</ref>
==Economic impact on the U.S. economy and its regions== There are few studies that focus on the impact of farmers' markets on the United States economy and on regional economies in the U.S. The [[USDA]] has the most research surrounding regional variation and overall composition of farmers' markets.
===Impact on U.S. economy=== In 2012, the [[output (economics)|output]] generated by [[United States]] [[farm]]s contributed $166.9 billion to [[gross domestic product]], which was 1 percent of [[GDP]]. This figure includes all farms participating in economic activity, which suggests that the total contribution of [[farmers' market]]s to the [[economy of the United States|U.S. economy]] in terms of [[output (economics)|output]] is very small.<ref>{{cite web|title=Agriculture and Food Sectors and the Economy|url=http://ers.usda.gov/data-products/ag-and-food-statistics-charting-the-essentials/ag-and-food-sectors-and-the-economy.aspx.|website=USDA|publisher=USDA Economic Research Service|accessdate=19 December 2014}}</ref>
Nevertheless, the number of farmers' markets in the [[United States]] is growing rapidly, with [[economic growth|growth]] increasing by 8.6 percent per year on [[average]]. About 30 percent of these new markets are less than five years old and most of them report sales that are half the national [[average]]. These new markets have on average 22 [[vendor]]s compared to the national average of 31, and 430 [[customer]]s per week compared to the national average of 959. This explains why the growth in sales from $888 million in 2000 to $1 billion in 2005 was only 2.5 percent in spite of the rapid growth in the number of farmers' markets. The [[revenue]] generated from farmers' markets was $31,923 per month according to a 2005 [[USDA]] study.<ref name=survey>{{cite web|title=National Farmers Market Manager Survey|url=http://www.ams.usda.gov/AMSv1.0/getfile?dDocName=STELPRDC5077203.|publisher=USDA|accessdate=19 December 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Farmers' Market Sales by County.jpg|thumb|This map shows that the Far West and the mid-Atlantic regions of the United States have the most profitable farmers' markets.]]
===Regional variation=== The [[region]]s that have the most lucrative farmers' markets are the Far West and the [[Mid-Atlantic states|mid-Atlantic region]]. Managers of farmers' markets reported in a 2005 study that about 15 percent of the [[vendor]]s at their [[markets|market]] earned between $25,000 and $100,000 annually. This range was the largest reported level of [[income]] across the regions. The North Central and Rocky Mountain regions in contrast experienced the lowest level of [[sales]] with [[revenues|revenue]] between $1,000 and $5,000. This may be due in part to the [[seasonality|seasonal]] variability of different [[region]]s. The markets in the [[Rocky Mountains|Rocky Mountain]] region were open on [[average]] only 3.92 months, while markets in the Far West were open for 4.9 months on average. The Far West also experienced the greatest level of sales with $476,733 per market per year, while the Rocky Mountain region experienced the lowest level of sales with $90,169 per market per year.<ref name=survey />
==Economic impact on states and cities== Many studies assess the impact of [[farmers' market]]s in the United States on state economies and [[municipality|municipal]] economies. Most of these studies find that farmers' markets benefit state and local economies because they have direct and indirect effects on personal [[income]], job creation, and on [[output (economics)|output]] generated in other [[economic sector|sectors]] of the economy including [[manufacturing]] and [[transportation]].
===Iowa=== The Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship conducted a study in 2009 to measure the economic impact of farmers' markets in [[Iowa]] using the IMPLAN Input-Output (I-O) model. Iowa is fourth in the nation in terms of its number of farmers' markets and ranks second in terms of the number of farmers' markets [[per capita]].
The report shows that [[sales]] among Iowa farmers' markets increased by 92 percent since 2004, reaching $38.4 million in [[sales]] in 2009. The tables entitled "Market sales per city, 2004" and "Market sales per city, 2009" show the overall increase in sales among different areas of Iowa between 2004 and 2009.

Using the IMPLAN I-O model, the $38.4 million in farmers' market sales translated into "$59.4 million of gross sales among sectors in the Iowa [[economy]]." Additionally, the I-O model found that $12.2 million was linked to "personal [[income]] effects directly or indirectly related to farmers' market activity." The study also concluded that 374 jobs were directly linked to farmers' market activity, while 200 jobs were "indirectly attributed to the activity."<ref name=Otto />
The 2009 report also focused on how farmers' markets affect other [[economic sector|sectors]] of the Iowan economy. The two sectors of the economy most impacted by farmers' market activity were [[agriculture]] and [[mining]] and [[wholesale]] and [[retail]] [[trade]]. The direct impact on agriculture and mining was about $24,960,000, with another $1 million in "business-related indirect impact" and "consumer-related induced impact." [[Construction]], [[manufacturing]], [[transportation]], [[finance]], [[professional services]], and [[tertiary sector of the economy|personal services]] were not directly impacted, but between $1 million and $4 million generated in each sector reflected indirect and induced impacts of farmers' market activity. The table entitled "Output impact of Iowa farmers' market activities" shows these impacts.<ref name=Otto />

===Portland, Oregon=== The City of [[Portland, Oregon|Portland's]] Office of Sustainable Development (OSD) commissioned a report in 2008 to study the impact of Portland's 14 farmers' markets on "the regional Portland metro-area economy." The 14 farmers' markets studied in Portland had [[sales]] of approximately $11.2 million in the aggregate in 2007.
The study found that the direct impact of "spending at farmers' markets" stays within the [[region]], while sales at the traditional [[grocery store]] "leak outside the region." Therefore, the estimated direct impact of $11.2 million in farmers' market spending is equivalent to only $3.4 million "in economic impact in a traditional grocery market" due to [[importation]] of [[good (economics)|goods]] and [[household]] [[margin (economics)|marginal]] decision-making in the [[retail|retail sector]].
Using the IMPLAN Input-Output Model, the study also measured the economic impact of [[product (business)|product]] sales, prepared [[food]] sales, and management fees, or "the payment of market management [[fee]]s by vendors," on [[output (economics)|output]], [[employment]], and employee [[wage|compensation]] in the Portland [[economy]].
The study concluded that the 14 markets in Portland produced approximately $17 million in output, 150 jobs, and $3.2 million in employee compensation. The table entitled "Total est. economic impact of 14 Portland-area farmers' markets, 2007" shows how product sales, prepared food sales, and management fees impacted the Portland economy in 2007.<ref name=Yosick>{{cite web|last1=Yosick|first1=Bonnie Gee|title=Economic Impact of Portland's Farmers Markets|url=https://www.portlandoregon.gov/bps/article/236588|website=The City of Portland Oregon|publisher=Bonnie Gee Yosick LLC|accessdate=19 December 2014}}</ref>
