===Religious freedom=== Views of Islam in America affected debates regarding freedom of religion during the drafting of the state constitution of [[Pennsylvania]] in 1776. Constitutionalists promoted religious toleration while Anticonstitutionalists called for reliance on Protestant values in the formation of the state's republican government. The former group won out, and inserted a clause for religious liberty in the new state constitution. American views of Islam were influenced by favorable [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] writings from Europe, as well as Europeans who had long warned that Islam was a threat to Christianity and republicanism.<ref>Charles D. Russell, "Islam as a Danger to Republican Virtue: Broadening Religious Liberty in Revolutionary Pennsylvania", ''Pennsylvania History'', Summer 2009, Vol. 76 Issue 3, pp. 250–275</ref>
In 1776, [[John Adams]] published "[[Thoughts on Government]]", in which he mentions the Islamic prophet Muhammad as a "sober inquirer after truth" alongside Confucius, Zoroaster, Socrates, and other thinkers.
In 1785, [[George Washington]] stated a willingness to hire "Mahometans", as well as people of any nation or religion, to work on his private estate at Mount Vernon if they were "good workmen".<ref>{{cite web|last=Hutson |first=James H. |url=https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/0205/tolerance.html |title=The Founding Fathers and Islam |work=Library of Congress Information Bulletin |date= May 2002 |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050427225400/http://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/0205/tolerance.html |archivedate=April 27, 2005 |accessdate=December 16, 2017 }}</ref>
In 1790, the South Carolina legislative body granted [[Moors Sundry Act of 1790|special legal status]] to a community of Moroccans.
In 1797, President John Adams signed the [[Treaty of Tripoli]], declaring the United States had no "character of enmity against the laws, religion, or tranquillity, of [[Muslim|Mussulmen]]".<ref>[http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/diplomacy/barbary/bar1796t.htm Treaty of Peace and Friendship] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070916113305/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/diplomacy/barbary/bar1796t.htm |date=September 16, 2007 }} Article 11. The Avalon Project. Yale Law School.</ref>
[[File:Article 11.gif|thumb|upright=1.15|[[Treaty of Tripoli]], Article 11]]
In his [[The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin|autobiography]], published in 1791, [[Benjamin Franklin]] stated that he "did not disapprove" of a meeting place in Pennsylvania that was designed to accommodate preachers of all religions. Franklin wrote that "even if the Mufti of Constantinople were to send a missionary to preach Mohammedanism to us, he would find a pulpit at his service".<ref name="Earlyamerica.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.earlyamerica.com/lives/franklin/chapt10/ |title=The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin – Chapter 10 |publisher=Earlyamerica.com |date=February 27, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201185040/http://www.earlyamerica.com/lives/franklin/chapt10/ |archivedate=December 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Franklin also wrote an anti-slavery parody that claimed to be translation of the response of a government official at Algiers to a 17th-century petition to banish slavery there; the parody develops the theme that Europeans are specially suited for enslavement on cultural and religious grounds, and that there would be practical problems with abolishing slavery in North Africa; this satirizes similar arguments that were then made about the enslavement of Blacks in North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sniggle.net/historicus.php |title=Sniggle.net |publisher=Sniggle.net |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111203200932/http://sniggle.net/historicus.php |archivedate=December 3, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Thomas Jefferson]] defended religious freedom in America including those of Muslims. Jefferson explicitly mentioned Muslims when writing about the movement for religious freedom in [[Virginia]]. In his autobiography Jefferson wrote "[When] the [Virginia] bill for establishing religious freedom ... was finally passed, ... a singular proposition proved that its protection of opinion was meant to be universal. Where the preamble declares that coercion is a departure from the plan of the holy author of our religion, an amendment was proposed, by inserting the word 'Jesus Christ', so that it should read 'a departure from the plan of Jesus Christ, the holy author of our religion'. The insertion was rejected by a great majority, in proof that they meant to comprehend within the mantle of its protection the Jew and the Gentile, the Christian and [[Mahometan]], the Hindoo and infidel of every denomination."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://etext.virginia.edu/jefferson/quotations/jeff1650.htm |title=Thomas Jefferson – Subject Research Guides at UVa Library |publisher=Etext.virginia.edu |date=April 21, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205032639/http://etext.virginia.edu/jefferson/quotations/jeff1650.htm |archivedate=December 5, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> While President, Jefferson also participated in an [[iftar]] with the Ambassador of [[Tunisia]] in 1809.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/09/129232.htm |title=Remarks at the Annual State Department Iftaar Dinner |publisher=State.gov |date=September 15, 2009 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202015142/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2009a/09/129232.htm |archivedate=December 2, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
However, not all politicians were pleased with the religious neutrality of the Constitution, which prohibited any religious test. Anti-Federalists in the 1788 North Carolina ratifying convention opposed the new constitution; one reason was the fear that some day Catholics or Muslims might be elected president. William Lancaster said:.<ref>Denise A. Spellberg, "Could a Muslim Be President? An Eighteenth-Century Constitutional Debate, ''Eighteenth-Century Studies'' 39#4 (2006) pp. 485–506</ref> :Let us remember that we form a government for millions not yet in existence ... In the course of four or five hundred years, I do not know how it will work. This is most certain, that Papists may occupy that chair, and Mahometans may take it. I see nothing against it.
In 1788, Americans held inaccurate and often contradicting views of the [[Muslim world]], and used that in political arguments. For example, the anti-Federalists compared a strong central government to the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and the American army to Turkish Janissaries, arguing against a strong central government. On the other hand, [[Alexander Hamilton]] argued that despotism in the Middle East was the result of the Sultan not having enough power to protect his people from oppressive local governors; thus he argued for a stronger central government.<ref>Robert J. Allison, ''The Crescent Obscured: The United States and the Muslim World, 1776–1815'' (1995) pp. 57–59</ref>
==Modern Muslims== [[File:Turkish immigrant in New York.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|[[Turkish American|Turkish immigrant]] in New York (1912)]] [[File:A group of immigrants, most wearing fezzes.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A group of immigrants, most wearing fezzes, surrounding a large vessel which is decorated with the star and crescent symbol of [[Islam]] and the [[Ottoman Turks]] (1902–1913)]]
Small-scale migration to the U.S. by Muslims began in 1840, with the arrival of [[Yemeni-American|Yemenis]] and [[Turkish-Americans|Turks]],<ref name = Koszegi/> and lasted until [[World War I]]. Most of the immigrants, from Arab areas of the [[Ottoman Empire]], came with the purpose of making money and returning to their homeland. However, the economic hardships of 19th-century America prevented them from prospering, and as a result the immigrants settled in the United States permanently. These immigrants settled primarily in [[Dearborn, Michigan]]; [[Quincy, Massachusetts]]; and [[Ross, North Dakota|Ross]], [[North Dakota]]. Ross, North Dakota is the site of the first documented mosque and Muslim Cemetery, but it was abandoned and later torn down in the mid-1970s. A new mosque was built in its place in 2005.<ref name = M/>
* 1906: [[Bosniaks]] ([[Bosniaks|Bosnian Muslims]]) in [[Chicago, Illinois]], started the Džemijetul Hajrije (Jamaat al-Khayriyya) (The Benevolent Society; a social service organization devoted to Bosnian Muslims). This is the longest lasting incorporated Muslim community in the United States. They met in Bosnian coffeehouses and eventually opened the first Islamic Sunday School with curriculum and textbooks under Bosnian scholar Sheikh Ćamil Avdić (Kamil Avdich) (a graduate of al-Azhar and author of ''Survey of Islamic Doctrines''). * 1907: [[Lipka Tatar]] immigrants from the [[Podlasie]] region of [[Poland]] founded the first Muslim organization in [[New York City]], the American Mohammedan Society.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,758343,00.html | work=Time | title=Religion: Ramadan | date=November 15, 1937 | accessdate=May 5, 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826161237/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,758343,00.html | archivedate=August 26, 2009 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> * 1915: What is most likely the first American mosque was founded by [[Albanian-Americans|Albanian Muslims]] in [[Biddeford, Maine]]. A Muslim cemetery still exists there.<ref>Queen, Edward L., Stephen Prothero and Gardiner H. Shattuck Jr. 1996. The Encyclopedia of American Religious History. New York: Facts on File.</ref><ref name=Ghazali>{{Cite news |last = Ghazali |first = Abdul Sattar |title = The number of mosque attendants increasing rapidly in America |newspaper = American Muslim perspective |url = http://www.amp.ghazali.net/html/mosques_in_us.html |postscript = <!--None--> |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928142701/http://www.amp.ghazali.net/html/mosques_in_us.html |archivedate = September 28, 2007 |df = mdy-all }} </ref> * 1920: First Islamic mission station was established by [[Mufti Muhammad Sadiq]], an [[India]]n [[Ahmadi Muslim]] missionary, followed by the building of the [[Al-Sadiq Mosque]] in 1921. * 1929: The Ross Masjid in [[North Dakota]] was founded by Syrian Muslims, there is still a cemetery nearby.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://30mosques.com/archive2010/2010/09/day-22-ross-north-dakota-a-leap-in-time/ |title=Day 22: Ross, North Dakota – A Leap in Time |accessdate=July 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325132015/http://30mosques.com/archive2010/2010/09/day-22-ross-north-dakota-a-leap-in-time/ |archivedate=March 25, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * 1934: The oldest, still standing, building built specifically to be a [[Mother Mosque of America|mosque]] is established in [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]]. The Mosque is where [[Abdullah Igram]] a notable Muslim veteran would teach the Quran, Abdullah Igram later wrote a letter to President Eisenhower persuading him to add the M option (for Muslims) on military dog tags. * 1945: A mosque existed in [[Dearborn, Michigan]], home to the largest [[Arab-American]] population in the U.S.
Construction of mosques sped up in the 1920s and 1930s, and by 1952, there were over 20 mosques.<ref name = M/> Although the first mosque was established in the U.S. in 1915, relatively few mosques were founded before the 1960s. Eighty-seven percent of mosques in the U.S. were founded within the last three decades according to the Faith Communities Today (FACT) survey. [[California]] has more mosques than any other state.
==Sub-groups==
===Ahmadiyya=== {{Main|Ahmadiyya in the United States}} [[File:Dr. Maulana Mufti Muhammad Sadiq.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|[[Mufti Muhammad Sadiq]], first Muslim missionary and an [[Ahmadi Muslim]].]] The [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]] is the oldest continuous Muslim community in the United States. Ahmadi Muslims were among the earliest [[dawah|Muslim missionaries]] in [[United States|America]], the first being [[Mufti Muhammad Sadiq]], and between 1921 and 1925 alone they converted over 1000 people to Islam. Although at first their efforts were broadly concentrated over a large number of racial and ethnic groups, subsequent realization of the deep-seated racial tensions and discrimination made Ahmadi [[dawah|missionaries]] focus their attention on mainly [[African Americans]] and the Muslim immigrant community and became vocal proponents of the [[civil rights movement]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/52153988|title=Islam in the African-American experience|last=Brent.|first=Turner, Richard|date=2003|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0253343239|edition=2nd|location=Bloomington, Ind.|oclc=52153988}}</ref> Many Ahmadi Muslims fled countries like [[Pakistan]] due to persecution in recent times.<ref>Islam in the African-American Experience. p. 262. Richard Brent Turner (2003)</ref>
===Black Muslim movements=== {{Further|Black Muslims (disambiguation) {{!}} Black Muslims|American Society of Muslims}} [[File:Nobledrew.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Noble Drew Ali]] During the first half of the 20th century, a small number of African Americans established groups based on Islamic and Gnostic teachings. The first of such groups created was the [[Moorish Science Temple of America]], founded by Timothy Drew (Drew Ali) in 1913. Drew taught that black people were of Moorish origin but their Muslim identity was taken away through slavery and racial segregation, advocating the return to Islam of their Moorish ancestry.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/391620/Moorish-Science-Temple-of-America Moorish Science Temple of America] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516121323/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/391620/Moorish-Science-Temple-of-America |date=May 16, 2008 }} Britannica Online Encyclopedia. Retrieved November 13, 2009.</ref>
====Moorish Science Temple of America==== {{Main|Moorish Science Temple of America}} The Moorish Science Temple of America is an American organization founded in 1913 by Prophet Noble Drew Ali. He said they practiced the "Old Time Religion" of Islamism but he also drew inspiration from Mohammedanism, Buddhism, Christianity, [[Gnosticism]], and [[Taoism]]. Its significant divergences from mainstream Islam and strong African-American ethnic character<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/the-aging-of-the-moors/Content?oid=999633|title=The Aging of the Moors|work=Chicago Reader|accessdate=February 15, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223130455/http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/the-aging-of-the-moors/Content?oid=999633|archivedate=February 23, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> make its classification as an Islamic denomination a matter of debate among Muslims and scholars of religion.
Its primary tenet was the belief that they are the ancient [[Moab]]ites who inhabited the Northwestern and Southwestern shores of Africa. The organization also believes that their descendants after being conquered in Spain are slaves who were captured and held in slavery from 1779–1865 by their slaveholders.
Adherents of the Moorish Science Temple of America believe that the so-called "[[Negroid]] Asiatic" was the first human inhabitant of the Western Hemisphere. In their religious texts members refer to themselves as "Asiatics",<ref>The Holy Koran of the Moorish Science Temple of America Chapter XXV – "A Holy Covenant of the Asiatic Nation"</ref> within the teachings of Noble Drew Ali, the members are taught man cannot be a Negro, Colored Folk, Black people, Ethiopians or African-Americans, because these names were given to slaves by slave holders in 1779 and lasted until 1865 during the time of slavery.
The Moorish Science Temple of America is legally and lawfully recognized as the first and oldest Islamic Organization in America, with its current leader R. Jones-Bey.
====Nation of Islam==== [[File:Louis Farrakhan, smiling.jpg|left|thumb|upright=0.55|[[Louis Farrakhan]], leader of the [[Nation of Islam]] since 1981]] {{Main|Nation of Islam}} The [[Nation of Islam]] (NOI) was created in 1930 by [[Wallace Fard Muhammad]]. Fard drew inspiration for NOI doctrines from those of Timothy Drew's Moorish Science Temple of America. He provided three main principles which serve as the foundation of the NOI: "Allah is God, the white man is the devil and the so-called Negroes are the Asiatic Black People, the cream of the planet earth".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/10778634|title=From black Muslims to Muslims : the transition from separatism to Islam, 1930-1980|last=1946-|first=Marsh, Clifton E.,|date=1984|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810817050|location=Metuchen, N.J.|oclc=10778634}}</ref>
In 1934 [[Elijah Muhammad]] became the leader of the NOI, he [[Apotheosis|deified]] Fard, saying that he was an [[incarnation]] of God, and taught that he was a prophet who had been taught directly by God in the form of Fard. Two of the most famous people to join the NOI were [[Malcolm X]], who became the face of the NOI in the media, and [[Muhammad Ali]], who, while initially rejected, was accepted into the group shortly after his first world heavyweight championship victory.<ref name=JN>Jacob Neusner (2003). pp. 180–81. {{ISBN|978-0-664-22475-2}}.</ref> Both Malcolm X and Ali later became Sunni Muslims.
Malcolm X was one of the most influential leaders of the NOI and, in accordance with NOI doctrine, advocated the complete [[Black separatism|separation of blacks from whites]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Lomax |first=Louis E. |authorlink=Louis Lomax |title=When the Word Is Given: A Report on Elijah Muhammad, Malcolm X, and the Black Muslim World |year=1963 |publisher=World Publishing |location=Cleveland |oclc=1071204 |pages=149–52 }}</ref> He left the NOI after being silenced for 90 days (due to a [[Malcolm X#NOI response to his remarks on Kennedy assassination|controversial comment]] on the [[John F. Kennedy assassination]]), and proceeded to form [[Muslim Mosque, Inc.]] and the [[Organization of Afro-American Unity]] before his [[Haj|pilgrimage to Mecca]] and conversion to Sunni Islam. He is viewed as the first person to start the movement among African Americans towards Sunni Islam.
It was estimated that there were at least 20,000 members in 2006.<ref>Omar Sacirbey (May 16, 2006) [http://pewforum.org/news/display.php?NewsID=10521 Muslims Look to Blacks for Civil Rights Guidance] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306063500/http://pewforum.org/news/display.php?NewsID=10521 |date=March 6, 2008 }} Pew Forum. Retrieved 2009-07-29.</ref> However, today the group has a wide influence in the African American community. The first [[Million Man March]] took place in [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1995 and was followed later by another one in 2000 which was smaller in size but more inclusive, welcoming individuals other than just African American men.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/974906.stm Farrakhan backs racial harmony] BBC News (BBC). October 16, 2000. Retrieved 2009-09-08.</ref> The group sponsors cultural and academic education, economic independence, and personal and social responsibility. {{Nation of Islam|collapsed=1}} The Nation of Islam has received a great deal of criticism for its anti-white, anti-Christian, and anti-semitic teachings,<ref name="Dodoo">{{cite web |url=http://religiousmovements.lib.virginia.edu/nrms/Nofislam.html |title=Nation of Islam |first=Jan |last=Dodoo |publisher=[[University of Virginia]] |date=May 29, 2001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109121852/http://religiousmovements.lib.virginia.edu/nrms/Nofislam.html |archivedate=November 9, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and is listed as a [[hate group]] by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/map/hate.jsp?T=32&m=5 |title=Active U.S. Hate Groups in 2006 |accessdate=October 29, 2007 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027030429/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/map/hate.jsp?T=32&m=5 |archivedate=October 27, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=====Five-Percent Nation===== {{Main|Five-Percent Nation}} The Five-Percent Nation, sometimes referred to as NGE or NOGE, the "Nation of Gods and Earths", or the "Five Percenters", is an American organization founded in 1964 in the [[Harlem, New York|Harlem]] section of the borough of Manhattan, New York City, by a former member of the Nation of Islam named [[Clarence 13X]] (born Clarence Edward Smith and later known as "Allah the Father"). Clarence 13X, a former student of Malcolm X, left the Nation of Islam after a theological dispute with the Nation's leaders over the nature and identity of God.<ref name="npr.org">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5614846 |title=God, the Black Man and the Five Percenters |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=February 13, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119080426/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5614846 |archivedate=January 19, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Specifically, Clarence 13X denied that the Nation's [[biracial]] founder Wallace Fard Muhammad was Allah and instead taught that the black man was himself God personified.<ref name="npr.org"/>
Members of the group call themselves Allah's Five Percenters, which reflects the concept that ten percent of the people in the world know the truth of existence, and those [[elite]]s and [[espionage|agents]] opt to keep eighty-five percent of the world in ignorance and under their controlling thumb; the remaining five percent are those who know the truth and are determined to enlighten the rest.<ref name="HipHopWired">{{cite web |url=http://hiphopwired.com/2012/06/28/the-meaning-of-the-5-a-look-at-the-nation-of-gods-and-earths/ |title=The Meaning Of The 5%: A Look At The Nation Of Gods And Earths |website=Hip-Hop Wired |last=Chandler |first=D.L. |date=June 28, 2012 |accessdate=October 11, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012042550/http://hiphopwired.com/2012/06/28/the-meaning-of-the-5-a-look-at-the-nation-of-gods-and-earths/ |archivedate=October 12, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=====United Nation of Islam===== {{Main|United Nation of Islam}} The United Nation of Islam (UNOI) is a group based in Kansas City, Kansas. It was founded circa 1978 by Royall Jenkins, who continues to be the leader of the group and styles himself "Royall, Allah in Person".
=====Conversion to orthodox Sunni Islam===== After the death of Elijah Muhammad, he was succeeded by his son, [[Warith Deen Mohammed]]. Mohammed rejected many teachings of his father, such as the divinity of Fard Muhammad, and saw a white person as also a worshiper. As he took control of the organization, he quickly brought in new [[reform]]s.<ref>John Esposito (September 10, 2008) [http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/onfaith/panelists/john_esposito/2008/09/wd_mohammed_a_witness_for_true.html W. D. Mohammed: A Witness for True Islam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003084229/http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/onfaith/panelists/john_esposito/2008/09/wd_mohammed_a_witness_for_true.html |date=October 3, 2012 }} ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved 2009-06-21.</ref> He renamed it the World Community of al-Islam in the West; later it became the [[American Society of Muslims]]. It was estimated that there were 200,000 followers of W. D. Mohammed at the time.
W. D. Mohammed introduced teachings which were based on orthodox Sunni Islam.<ref name=RBT>Richard Brent Turner (2003). ''Islam in the African-American experience''. pp. 225–27. {{ISBN|978-0-253-21630-4}}.</ref> He removed the chairs in the organization's [[temple]]s, and replaced the entire "temple" concept with the traditional Muslim house of worship, the [[mosque]], also teaching how to pray the ''[[salat]]'', to observe the fasting of [[Ramadan]], and to attend the [[Hajj|pilgrimage to Mecca]].<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26630405/Former Nation of Islam leader dies at 74] MSNBC. Retrieved June 21, 2009.</ref>
A small number of Black Muslims however rejected these new reforms brought by Imam Mohammed. [[Louis Farrakhan]], who broke away from the organization, re-established the Nation of Islam under the original Fardian doctrines, and remains its leader.<ref name=ind>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/warith-deen-mohammed-imam-who-preached-a-moderate-form-of-islam-to-black-americans-930887.html Warith Deen Mohammed: Imam who preached a moderate form of Islam to black Americans] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122225812/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/warith-deen-mohammed-imam-who-preached-a-moderate-form-of-islam-to-black-americans-930887.html |date=November 22, 2014 }} The Independent. September 15, 2008. Retrieved April 22, 2009.</ref>
===Shia Islam=== {{See also|Shia Islam in the Americas}} An estimated 786,000 [[Shiism|Shia Muslims]] live in the United States.<ref>{{cite book|author=Zahid Hussain Bukhari|title=Muslims' Place in the American Public Square: Hope, Fears, and Aspirations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jXl2Z2PI3xMC&pg=PR37|year=2004|publisher=Rowman Altamira|isbn=978-0-7591-0613-0|page=xxxvii}}</ref> They originate from [[South Asia]], [[Europe]], [[Middle East]], and [[East Africa]].<ref name=Brumberg2009>{{cite book|author1=Daniel Brumberg|author2=Dina Shehata|title=Conflict, Identity, and Reform in the Muslim World: Challenges for U.S. Engagement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dtXXV8dtCpsC&pg=PA366|year=2009|publisher=US Institute of Peace Press|isbn=978-1-60127-020-7|pages=366–70}}</ref> The "heart of Shiism in the U.S." is placed in Dearborn,<ref>{{cite news|first=Rachel |last=Zoll |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=20090725&id=MmJfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XlwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6836,3891309 |title=American Shias struggle with future |newspaper=The Victoria Advocate |date=July 25, 2009 |page=E3}}</ref> home to the [[Islamic Center of America]]. The North American Shia Ithna-Asheri Muslim Communities Organization (NASIMCO) is the largest umbrella group for North American Shias.<ref name=Brumberg2009/>
===Sufism=== Some Muslim Americans adhere to the doctrines of [[Sufism]]. The [[Islamic Supreme Council of America]] (ISCA) is a small body representing [[Sufi]] teachings, which, according to adherents, is the inner, mystical dimension of Islam. The ISCA's stated aims include providing practical solutions for American Muslims, based on the traditional Islamic legal rulings of an international advisory board, many of whom are recognized as the highest ranking Islamic scholars in the world. ISCA aims to integrate traditional scholarship in resolving contemporary issues affecting the maintenance of Islamic beliefs in a modern, secular society.<ref name="islamicsupremecouncil.org">[http://www.islamicsupremecouncil.org/home/about-us.html Islamic Supreme Council of America: Our Mission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529175753/http://www.islamicsupremecouncil.org/home/about-us.html |date=May 29, 2010 }}.</ref> It has been linked to [[Neoconservatism|neoconservative thought]].
===Quranic movement=== The largest [[Quranism|Quranist]] movement in the United States is the [[United Submitters International]]. This movement was founded by [[Rashad Khalifa]]. His movement popularized the phrase: "The Qur'an, the whole Qur'an, and nothing but the Qur'an". Although he was initially well received by many, his subsequent claims of divine inspiration caused friction between him and others, and he was assassinated in 1990.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgarian+faces+life+sentence+1990+murder+controversial/7743101/story.html |last1=KOMARNICKI |first1=Jamie |title=Calgarian faces life sentence for 1990 murder of controversial U.S. imam |accessdate=July 2, 2014 |date=December 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228235110/http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgarian%2Bfaces%2Blife%2Bsentence%2B1990%2Bmurder%2Bcontroversial/7743101/story.html |archivedate=December 28, 2012 |quote=More than two decades after a controversial imam was found stabbed to death inside his Tucson mosque, an Arizona jury has found former Calgarian Glen Cusford Francis guilty of first-degree murder in the case. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Notable Americans influenced by Rashad Khalifa include his son, [[Sam Khalifa]], a retired professional baseball player and [[Ahmad Rashād]], a sportscaster and retired football player.
===Non-denominational Muslims=== [[Non-denominational Muslim]]s make up roughly one in seven of all American Muslims, at 15%. Non-denominational Muslims, do not have any specific affiliation with a religious body and usually describe themselves as being "just a Muslim". Muslims who were born in the US are more likely to be non-denominational than immigrant Muslims. 24% or one in four US-born Muslims are non-denominational, versus 10% of immigrant Muslims.<ref>Section 2: Religious Beliefs and Practices, Pew Research Center</ref>
===Other Muslims=== There are some mosquegoers who adhere to sects and denominations that form very small minorities. Examples of such small branches include [[progressive Muslim]]s, [[Mahdavi Muslim]]s and [[Ibadi Muslim]]s.<ref>Deconstructing the American Mosque: Space, Gender, and Aesthetics, p. 145, Akel Ismail Kahera (2010)</ref><ref>Encyclopedia of Muslim-American History. p. 473, Edward E. Curtis (2010)</ref><ref>Immigrant and Minority Entrepreneurship: p. 5, John Sibley Butler, George Kozmetsky. (2004)</ref>
==Demographics== [[File:Ethnic composition of Muslim Americans.png|thumb|According to the [[U.S. Department of State]] (2009), the largest ethnic groups of American Muslims are those of South Asian, Arab and African-American descent.]] [[File:A PORTION OF A CROWD OF SOME 10,000 MUSLIMS APPLAUD ELIJAH MUHAMMAD DURING THE DELIVERY OF HIS ANNUAL SAVIOR'S DAY... - NARA - 556243.jpg|thumb|A crowd of Black Muslims applaud during [[Elijah Muhammad]]'s annual [[Saviors' Day]] message in Chicago in 1974]] [[File: Islamic Cultural Center E96 jeh.JPG|thumb|[[Islamic Cultural Center of New York]], [[Manhattan]], in [[New York City]].]] [[File:Iftar in Patterson New Jersey.jpg|thumb|right|[[Paterson, New Jersey]], within the [[New York City Metropolitan Area]], has been nicknamed ''[[Little Ramallah]]'', contains a neighborhood with the same name, and is becoming an increasingly popular destination for Muslim immigrants.]] [[File:Islamic Center of Greater Toledo OH.jpg|thumb|Islamic Center of [[Toledo, Ohio|Greater Toledo]], [[Ohio]].]] [[File:Jerusalem is Forever The Capital of Palestine 163825.jpg|thumb|Protest against [[United States recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel|U.S. recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], 11 December 2017]]
The U.S. Census Bureau does not collect data on religious identification. Various institutions and organizations have given widely varying estimates about how many Muslims live in the U.S. Tom W. Smith, author of "Estimating the Muslim Population in the United States", said that of twenty estimates he reviewed during a five-year period until 2001, none was "based on a scientifically-sound or explicit methodology. All can probably be characterized as guesses or assertions. Nine came from Muslim organizations such as the Islamic Society of North America, the Muslim Student Association, the Council on American-Islamic Relations, the American Muslim Council, and the Harvard Islamic Society or unspecified 'Muslim sources'. None of these sources gave any basis for their figures."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ajc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=ijITI2PHKoG&b=843637&ct=1044159 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206134924/http://www.ajc.org/site/apps/nl/content3.asp?c=ijITI2PHKoG&b=843637&ct=1044159 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 6, 2006 |title=Tom W. Smith, Estimating the Muslim Population in the United States, New York, The American Jewish Committee, October 2001 |publisher=Ajc.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 }}</ref> In 2005, according to ''[[The New York Times]]'', more people from Muslim countries became legal permanent United States residents—nearly 96,000—than in any year in the previous two decades.<ref name=autogenerated8 /><ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref name="allied-media.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.allied-media.com/AM/index.html |title=American Muslim Demographics – Muslim American Populations Outreach Programs |publisher=Allied-media.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106004716/http://www.allied-media.com/AM/index.html |archivedate=November 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
According to CAIR, no scientific count of Muslims in the U.S. has been done and the larger figures should be considered accurate. Some journalists have also alleged that the higher numbers have been inflated for political purposes.<ref>[http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_islam_usa.html Number of Muslims in the United States] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104062043/http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_islam_usa.html |date=January 4, 2007 }} at Adherents.com. Retrieved January 6, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/headlines/20011028usmuslimsnat7p7.asp Private studies fuel debate over size of U.S. Muslim population] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041212184558/http://www.post-gazette.com/headlines/20011028usmuslimsnat7p7.asp |date=December 12, 2004 }} – ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''. October 28, 2001.</ref>
According to a Pew Forum estimate, in 2017 there were 3.45 million Muslims, constituting about 1.1% of the total U.S. population.<ref name=Pew2017/> A Pew Forum report on American religion found that Muslims accounted for 0.9% of American adults in 2014, up from 0.4% in 2007, due largely to immigration. Retention rates were high, at 77%, similar to Hindus (80%) and Jews (75%); most people who leave these religions become unaffiliated, although ex-Muslims were more likely to be Christians than ex-Hindus or ex-Jews were. Conversely, 23% of American Muslims were converts, including 8% from historically black Protestant traditions, 6% from being unaffiliated, 4% from Catholicism, and 3% from mainline or evangelical Protestantism. By race, in 2014, 38% were non-Hispanic white (including Arabs and Iranians, up from 32% in 2007), 28% were Asian (mostly Indians, Pakistanis, and Bangladeshis, up from 20% in 2007), 28% were black (down from 32%), 4% Hispanic (down from 7%), and 3% of mixed or other race (down from 7%). Since 2007, the black proportion had shrunk, while the white and Asian proportions had grown, mainly due to immigration as most black Muslims were native U.S. blacks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pewforum.org/2015/05/12/americas-changing-religious-landscape/ |title=America’s Changing Religious Landscape |date=May 12, 2015 |publisher=Pew Research |accessdate=May 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623114225/http://www.pewforum.org/2015/05/12/americas-changing-religious-landscape/ |archivedate=June 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In January 2018, the [[Pew Research Center]] projected that by 2040, Muslims will replace [[American Jews|Jews]] as the second-largest religious group in the U.S. (after [[Christianity in the United States|Christians]]). By 2050, the number of American Muslims was projected to be twice the size of the 2017 Muslim population. Pew cited high fertility rates among American Muslims and immigration of Muslims to the U.S. as the reasons for the growth. It said that religious conversion was not expected to be a significant factor, because the number of American converts to Islam is roughly the same as the number of people who leave the religion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2018/01/03/new-estimates-show-u-s-muslim-population-continues-to-grow/ |title=New estimates show U.S. Muslim population continues to grow |first=Besheer |last=Mohamed |date=January 3, 2018 |publisher=[[Pew Research Center]] |accessdate=January 6, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105211330/http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2018/01/03/new-estimates-show-u-s-muslim-population-continues-to-grow/ |archivedate=January 5, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Race=== According to a 2001 study written by Ihsan Bagby, an associate professor of Islamic studies at the [[University of Kentucky]], of Americans who convert to Islam, 64% are [[African-American Muslims|African American]], 27% are White, 6% are [[Hispanic Muslim|Hispanic]] of any race, and 3% are other. Around that time increasing numbers of American Hispanics converted to Islam. Many [[Hispanic and Latino American Muslims|Hispanic converts]] in [[Houston]] said that they often had been mistaken as of being of Pakistani or Middle Eastern descent, due to their religion. Many Hispanic converts were former Christians.<ref>Dooley, Tara. "[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FBZZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bkYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6791,6168079&dq=statistics+religion+houston+area+muslims&hl=en Muslims gain Hispanic converts]". ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' at ''[[The Victoria Advocate]]''. Saturday September 28, 2002. 2D and 3D. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] (45–46 of 51) on February 19, 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cair.com/images/pdf/The-American-mosque-2001.pdf |title=The Mosque in America: A National Portrait |first1=Ihsan |last1=Bagby |first2=Paul M. |last2=Perl |first3=Bryan T. |last3=Froehle |date=April 26, 2001 |publisher=Council on American-Islamic Relations |page=21 |accessdate=February 19, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006214638/http://www.cair.com/images/pdf/The-American-mosque-2001.pdf |archivedate=October 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Since the arrival of South Asian and Arab communities during the 1990s there has been divisions with the African Americans due to the racial and cultural differences; however, since September 11, 2001, the two groups joined together when the immigrant communities looked towards the African Americans for advice on [[civil rights]].<ref>Andrea Elliot (March 11, 2007) [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/11/nyregion/11muslim.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&sq=african%20american%20muslims&st=cse&scp=5 Between Black and Immigrant Muslims, an Uneasy Alliance] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102120130/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/11/nyregion/11muslim.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&sq=african%20american%20muslims&st=cse&scp=5 |date=January 2, 2017 }} ''The New York Times''. Retrieved 2009-07-23.</ref>
===Religion=== According to a 2014 religious survey, 64% of Muslims believe religion is very important, compared to 58% of Catholics who believe so. The frequency of receiving answers to prayers among Muslims was, 31% at least once a week and 12% once or twice a month.<ref>[http://religions.pewforum.org/pdf/beliefs_portrait-Muslims.pdf Portrait of Muslims – Beliefs & Practices] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125054035/http://religions.pewforum.org/pdf/beliefs_portrait-Muslims.pdf |date=January 25, 2009 }} Pew Research Center</ref> Nearly a quarter of the Muslims are converts to Islam (23%), mainly native-born. Of the total who have converted, 59% are African American and 34% white. Previous religions of those converted was [[Protestantism]] (67%), [[Roman Catholicism]] (10%), and 15% no religion.
[[Mosque]]s are usually explicitly Sunni or Shia although they are over 55 [[Ahmadiyya]] mosques as well. There are 2,106 mosques in the United States {{as of|2010|lc=y}},<ref>{{cite news |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/religion/story/2012-02-29/islamic-worship-growth-us/53298792/1 |title=Number of U.S. mosques up 74% since 2000 |first=Cathy Lynn |last=Grossman |date=February 29, 2012 |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=July 17, 2015 }}</ref> and the nation's largest mosque, the [[Islamic Center of America]], is in [[Dearborn, Michigan]]. It caters mainly to the Shia Muslim congregation; however, all Muslims may attend this mosque. It was rebuilt in 2005 to accommodate over 3,000 people for the increasing Muslim population in the region.<ref>[http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2005/June/20050602172516xbtterrets0.4066889.html Detroit Islamic Center Open Largest Mosque in United States] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104042821/http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2005/June/20050602172516xbtterrets0.4066889.html |date=November 4, 2010 }} Brittany Sterrett. June 2, 2005 Accessed August 19, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.gc.cuny.edu/faculty/research_briefs/aris/aris_part_two.htm Profile of the U.S. Muslim population] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612210429/http://www.gc.cuny.edu/faculty/research_briefs/aris/aris_part_two.htm |date=June 12, 2010 }}, Dr Barry A. Kosmin & Dr Egon Mayer, October 2, 2001</ref> Approximately half (50%) of the religious affiliations of Muslims is Sunni, 16% [[Shia]], 22% non-affiliated and 16% other/non-response.<ref name="PewForum">{{cite web|url=http://pewresearch.org/assets/pdf/muslim-americans.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916051122/http://pewresearch.org/assets/pdf/muslim-americans.pdf |archivedate=September 16, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Muslims of Arab descent are mostly Sunni (56%) with minorities who are Shia (19%). Muslims of South Asian descent including [[Bangladeshis]] (90%), [[Indian people|Indians]] (82%) and [[Pakistanis]] (72%) are mainly Sunni, other groups such as [[Iran]]ians are mainly Shia (91%).<ref name=PewForum/> Of African American Muslims, 48% are Sunni, 34% are unaffiliated (mostly part of the ''Community of W.Deen Mohammed''), 16% other (mostly Nation of Islam and [[Ahmadiyya]]) and 2% Shia.<ref name=PewForum/>
In many areas, a mosque may be dominated by whatever group of immigrants is the largest. Sometimes the Friday sermons, or [[khutba]]s, are given in languages like [[Urdu]], [[Bengali language|Bengali]] or [[Arabic language|Arabic]] along with [[English language|English]]. Areas with large Muslim populations may support a number of mosques serving different immigrant groups or varieties of belief within Sunni or Shia traditions. At present, many mosques are served by imams who immigrate from overseas, as only these imams have certificates from Muslim seminaries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shariahboard.org/Docs/DarulUloom_admission_brochure.pdf |title=Darul Uloom Chicago |accessdate=August 19, 2007 |format=PDF |work= |publisher=Shari'ah Board of America |page=2 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061016163653/http://shariahboard.org/Docs/DarulUloom_admission_brochure.pdf |archivedate = October 16, 2006}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated6>{{cite news |first=Jeff |last=Jacoby |title=The Boston mosque's Saudi connection |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2007/01/10/the_boston_mosques_saudi_connection/ |work= |publisher=''The Boston Globe'' |date=January 10, 2007 |accessdate=June 15, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070216143949/http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2007/01/10/the_boston_mosques_saudi_connection/ |archivedate=February 16, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite web |url=https://www.senate.gov/~schumer/SchumerWebsite/pressroom/press_releases/PR02009.html |title=Schumer: Saudis playing role in spreading main terror influence in United States |accessdate=June 15, 2007 |work=United States Senator Charles Schumer |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070610042932/https://www.senate.gov/~schumer/SchumerWebsite/pressroom/press_releases/PR02009.html |archivedate = June 10, 2007}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/library/congress/2003_h/030626-alexiev.htm |title=Terrorism: Growing Wahhabi Influence in the United States |accessdate=June 15, 2007 |last=Alexiev |first=Alex |work= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618005409/http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/library/congress/2003_h/030626-alexiev.htm |archivedate=June 18, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Data from the [[General Social Survey]] in the United States show that 32 percent of those raised Muslim no longer embrace Islam in adulthood, and 18 percent hold no religious identification.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/2015-06-22/losing-their-religion |title=Losing Their Religion: When Muslim Immigrants Leave Islam |first=Darren E. |last=Sherkat |authorlink=Darren Sherkat |date=June 22, 2015 |work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |accessdate=May 11, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407112126/https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/2015-06-22/losing-their-religion |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Education and income=== The household income levels of American Muslims are about as evenly distributed as the general American population.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/10/11/how-income-varies-among-u-s-religious-groups/|title=How income varies among U.S. religious groups|author=|date=October 11, 2016|website=pewresearch.org|accessdate=April 28, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221015534/http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/10/11/how-income-varies-among-u-s-religious-groups/|archivedate=February 21, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
When it comes to education, the Institute for Social Policy and Understanding reported in 2017 that across the board, American Muslims, Protestants, and Catholics have similar education levels. It has also been found that Muslim women (73%) are more likely than Muslim men (57%) to go on to pursue higher education beyond high school, and they are also more likely to report being in the middle class.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ispu.org/american-muslim-poll-2017-key-findings/|title=American Muslim Poll 2017: Key Findings {{!}} ISPU|date=2017-03-21|work=Institute for Social Policy and Understanding|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
Among South Asians in the country, the large Pakistani American community stands out as particularly well educated and prosperous, with education and income levels exceeding those of U.S.-born whites. Many are [[professionals]], especially in medicine (they account for 2.7-5% of America’s physicians),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Curlin, MD|first1=Farr A|last2=Lantos, MD|first2=John D|last3=Roach, BS|first3=Chad J|last4=Sellergren, MA|first4=Sarah A|last5=Chin, MD, MPH|first5=Marshall H|title=Religious Characteristics of U.S. Physicians – A National Survey|journal=Journal of General Internal Medicine|volume=20|issue=7|pages=629–634|pmc=1490160|year=2005|doi=10.1111/j.1525-1497.2005.0119.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Abu-Ras|first1=W.|last2=Laird|first2=L.D.|last3=Senzai|first3=F.|title=A Window Into American Muslim Physicians: Civic Engagement and Communitu Participation|url=https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.imana.org/resource/resmgr/ispu_report_muslim_physician.pdf|website=Islamic Medical Association of North America (IMANA)|publisher=Institute for Social Policy and Understanding (ISPU)|accessdate=March 9, 2016|pages=9, 11|date=October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310174114/https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.imana.org/resource/resmgr/ispu_report_muslim_physician.pdf|archivedate=March 10, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> scientists, engineers, and financial analysts, and there are also a large number of entrepreneurs. There are more than 15,000 medical doctors practicing medicine in the USA who are of Pakistani origin alone<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/extract/356/5/442|title=Pakistani Physicians and the Repatriation Equation|accessdate=March 5, 2015|doi=10.1056/NEJMp068261|volume=356|issue=5|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|pages=442–443|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011002640/http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/extract/356/5/442|archivedate=October 11, 2008|df=mdy-all|year=2007|last1=Shafqat|first1=Saad|last2=Zaidi|first2=Anita K.M}}</ref> and the number of Pakistani American millionaires was reported to be in the thousands. [[Shahid Khan]] a Pakistani-born American multi [[billionaire]] businessmen owner of the Jacksonville Jaguars of the National Football League (NFL) making him the first and only ethnic minority member to own one, he also owns English Premier League team Fulham F.C., and automobile parts manufacturer Flex-N-Gate in Urbana, Illinois.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/1298/9812104.html|title=Muslim-American Activisms: 'Vision' Examined at AMA's Third Annual Convention|work=Washington Report on Middle East Affairs (WRMEA)|accessdate=March 5, 2015}}</ref>
45 percent of immigrant Muslims report annual household income levels of $50,000 or higher. This compares to the national average of 44 percent. Immigrant Muslims are well represented among higher-income earners, with 19 percent having annual household incomes of $100,000 or higher (compared to 16 percent for the Muslim population as a whole and 17 percent for the U.S. average). This is likely due to the strong concentration of Muslims in professional, managerial, and technical fields, especially in information technology, education, medicine, law, and the corporate world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.america.gov/st/peopleplace-english/2008/December/20081222090246jmnamdeirf0.4547083.html |title=Muslims in America – A Statistical Portrait |publisher=America.gov |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014023151/http://www.america.gov/st/peopleplace-english/2008/December/20081222090246jmnamdeirf0.4547083.html |archivedate=October 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Conversion to Islam in prisons=== {{main|Conversion to Islam in U.S. prisons}} In addition to immigration, the state, federal and local prisons of the United States may be a contributor to the growth of Islam in the country. According to J. Michael Waller, Muslim inmates constitute 15–20% of the prison population, or roughly 350,000 inmates in 2003. Waller states that these inmates mostly come into prison as non-Muslims. He also says that 80% of the prisoners who "find faith" while in prison convert to Islam.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://judiciary.senate.gov/hearings/testimony.cfm?id=4f1e0899533f7680e78d03281ff19bc6&wit_id=4f1e0899533f7680e78d03281ff19bc6-2-1 |title=Statement of J. Michael Waller, Annenberg Professor of International Communication, Institute of World Politics, Before the Subcommittee on Terrorism, Technology and Homeland Security, Senate Committee on the Judiciary |first=J. Michael |last=Waller |date=October 14, 2003 |publisher=United States Senate |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527173646/http://www.judiciary.senate.gov/hearings/testimony.cfm?id=4f1e0899533f7680e78d03281ff19bc6&wit_id=4f1e0899533f7680e78d03281ff19bc6-2-1 |archivedate=May 27, 2012 |accessdate=January 19, 2017 }}</ref> These converted inmates are mostly African American, with a small but growing Hispanic minority. Waller also asserts that many converts are radicalized by outside [[Islamism|Islamist]] groups linked to terrorism, but other experts suggest that when radicalization does occur it has little to no connection with these outside interests.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/congress/congress06/vanduyn092006.htm Federal Bureau of Investigation – Congressional Testimony] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060925222510/https://www.fbi.gov/congress/congress06/vanduyn092006.htm |date=September 25, 2006 }}</ref><ref>United State Senate, Committee on the Judiciary, Testimony of Mr. Paul Rogers, President of the American Correctional Chaplains Association, October 12, 2003 [http://judiciary.senate.gov/testimony.cfm?id=960&wit_id=2717 Judiciary.senate.gov] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828205813/http://judiciary.senate.gov/testimony.cfm?id=960&wit_id=2717 |date=August 28, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/oig/special/0404/final.pdf |title=Special Report: A Review of the Federal Bureau of Prisons' Selection of Muslim Religious Services Providers – Full Report |format=PDF |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530105458/http://www.usdoj.gov/oig/special/0404/final.pdf |archivedate=May 30, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Population concentration=== [[File:Muslim Population by Percentage in United States, 2014.svg|thumb|upright=2|The Muslim population of the United States in 2014, shown by the percentage of the population in each state]] There were calculated to be 2.595 million Muslim adherents across the United States in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://religions.pewforum.org/reports|title=Statistics on Religion in America Report – Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life|publisher=|accessdate=March 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EW1WLjh6?url=http://religions.pewforum.org/reports|archivedate=February 18, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Islamic populations are 0.6% of the US population per [[Fareed Zakaria]] quoting Pew Research Center, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/01/27/future-of-the-global-muslim-population-regional-americas/|title=Region: Americas|date=January 27, 2011|work=Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project|accessdate=March 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308235757/http://www.pewforum.org/2011/01/27/future-of-the-global-muslim-population-regional-americas/|archivedate=March 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], was estimated to have 30,000 to 50,000 Muslims as of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/community/religion/Paterson_Muslims_to_picket_Lowes_for_pulling_ads_from_TV_series.html|title=Paterson Muslims to picket Lowe’s for pulling ads from TV series|author=Justo Bautista|publisher=North Jersey Media Group|date=December 13, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016214116/http://www.northjersey.com/community/religion/Paterson_Muslims_to_picket_Lowes_for_pulling_ads_from_TV_series.html|archivedate=October 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Paterson, New Jersey, has been nicknamed ''[[Little Ramallah]]'' and contains a neighborhood with the same name, with an Arab American population estimated as high as 20,000 in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/palestinian-flag-raising-is-highlight-of-heritage-week-in-paterson-1.1324680|title=Palestinian flag-raising is highlight of heritage week in Paterson|author=Deena Yellin|publisher=North Jersey Media Group|date=May 3, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505040613/http://www.northjersey.com/news/palestinian-flag-raising-is-highlight-of-heritage-week-in-paterson-1.1324680|archivedate=May 5, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Mosques=== The number of mosques in the United States in 2011 was 2,106. The six states with the greatest number of mosques were: [[New York (state)|New York]] 257, [[California]] 246, [[Texas]] 166, [[Florida]] 118, [[Illinois]] 109, [[New Jersey]] 109.<ref>http://faithcommunitiestoday.org/sites/faithcommunitiestoday.org/files/The%20American%20Mosque%202011%20web.pdf{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Culture== {{see also|Hijab by country#United States}} [[File:StangoAli.jpg|thumb|upright=0.4|left|Pop art painting of [[Muhammad Ali]].]] Muslims in the United States have increasingly made their own culture; there are various Muslim comedy groups, rap groups, Scout troops and magazines, and Muslims have been vocal in other forms of media as well.<ref>Patricia Smith. "Islam in America", ''New York Times Upfront''. New York: January 9, 2006. Vol. 138, Iss. 8; p. 10</ref>
Within the Muslim community in the United States there exist a number of different traditions. As in the rest of the world, the Sunni Muslims are in the majority. Shia Muslims, especially those in the Iranian immigrant community, are also active in community affairs. All four major schools of Islamic jurisprudence ([[fiqh]]) are found among the Sunni community.
Some Muslims in the U.S. are also adherents of certain global movements within Islam such as the [[Salafism|Salafi]], the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], the [[Gülen Movement#The Gülen movement|Gülen movement]], and the [[Tablighi Jamaat]].
As of December 2013 increasing numbers of Muslim Americans are [[Christmas traditions#United States|celebrating Christmas]];<ref>Staff Writer. "[http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/art-and-culture/2013/12/24/Muslim-Americans-increasingly-celebrate-Christmas.html Muslim-Americans increasingly celebrate Christmas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226191022/http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/art-and-culture/2013/12/24/Muslim-Americans-increasingly-celebrate-Christmas.html |date=December 26, 2013 }}". ''[[Al Arabiya]]''. December 24, 2013. Retrieved December 26, 2013.</ref> Jesus is [[Jesus in Islam|a holy prophet in Islam]].
==Politics== In the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 Presidential election]], nearly 80 percent of Muslim Americans supported Republican candidate [[George W. Bush]] over [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate [[Al Gore]]. However, due to the invasions of [[Invasion of Afghanistan, 2001|Afghanistan]] and [[Operation Iraqi Freedom|Iraq]] which took place under the [[George W. Bush|Bush Administration]], as well as what some call an increased anti-Muslim rhetoric from the Republican Party after the [[September 11 attacks]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/azeem-ibrahim/muslim-voters-2012_b_1247616.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111235311/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/azeem-ibrahim/muslim-voters-2012_b_1247616.html |archivedate=November 11, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Muslims in America 2012 – Who Will They Vote For?</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amuslimvoice.org/html/body_after_11_years.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112020208/http://www.amuslimvoice.org/html/body_after_11_years.html |archivedate=November 12, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} American Muslims remain in the dock 11 years after 9/11 by Abdus Sattar Ghazali</ref> support for the Republican Party among American Muslims has declined sharply.
By [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004]], Bush's Muslim support had been reduced by at least half, who would vote for Democratic candidate [[John Kerry]] or a third party candidate.<ref>{{cite web |author=Brian Beutler |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/08/republican-muslims-to-gop-youre-on-thin-ice.php |title=GOP Muslims Fear Failure Of Bush Outreach Efforts After Anti-Mosque Furor | TPMDC |publisher=Tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101190636/http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/08/republican-muslims-to-gop-youre-on-thin-ice.php |archivedate=January 1, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

==Organizations==
One of the largest Islamic organizations is the [[Islamic Society of North America]] (ISNA) which says that 27% of mosques in U.S. are associated with it. ISNA is an association of immigrant Muslim organizations and individuals that provides a common platform for presenting Islam. It is composed mostly of immigrants. Its membership may have recently exceeded ASM, as many independent mosques throughout the United States are choosing to affiliate with it. ISNA's annual convention is the largest gathering of Muslims in the United States.<ref>[http://www.isna.net Islamic Society of North America Official Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041017011936/http://isna.net/ |date=October 17, 2004 }}.</ref>
The second largest is the community under the leadership of W.Deen Mohammed or the [[American Society of Muslims]] with 19% of mosques, mostly African-Americans having an affiliation with it. It was the successor organization to the [[Nation of Islam]], once better-known as the Black Muslims. The association recognizes the leadership of [[Warith Deen Mohammed]]. This group evolved from the [[black separatism|Black separatist]] [[Nation of Islam]] (1930–1975). The majority of its members are African Americans. This has been a 23-year process of religious reorientation and organizational decentralization, in the course of which the group was known by other names, such as the [[American Muslim Mission]], W.Deen Mohammed guided its members to the practice of mainstream Islam such as salat or fasting, and teaching the basic creed of Islam the ''[[shahadah]]''.
The third largest group is the [[Islamic Circle of North America]] (ICNA). ICNA describes itself as a non-ethnic, open to all, independent, [[North America]]-wide, grass-roots organization. It is composed mostly of immigrants and the children of immigrants. It is growing as various independent mosques throughout the United States join and also may be larger than ASM at the present moment. Its youth division is [[Young Muslims]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icna.org/ |title=Islamic Circle of North America Official Website |publisher=Icna.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204161946/http://www.icna.org/ |archivedate=December 4, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Why Islam?]] is a community outreach project of ICNA;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euro-islam.info/country-profiles/united-states/|title=Islam in the United States|publisher=|accessdate=March 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150313100411/http://www.euro-islam.info/country-profiles/united-states|archivedate=March 13, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Message">Sherri Day, [http://www.tampabay.com/news/religion/muslims-take-message-on-the-road/937236 "Muslims take message on the road"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812211331/http://www.tampabay.com/news/religion/muslims-take-message-on-the-road/937236 |date=August 12, 2014 }}, ''Tampa Bay Times'', December 13, 2008</ref> it seeks to provide accurate information about Islam<ref>Star-Ledger Editorial Board, [http://blog.nj.com/njv_editorial_page/2011/08/why_islam_fights_misunderstand.html "Why Islam? fights misunderstanding with the facts"] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20140618134725/http://blog.nj.com/njv_editorial_page/2011/08/why_islam_fights_misunderstand.html |date=June 18, 2014 }}, ''The Star-Ledger'', August 10, 2011</ref> while debunking popular stereotypes and common misconceptions through various services and outreach activities.<ref name="Billboard Blitz">Liane Membis, [http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/08/15/billboard-blitz-for-877-why-islam/ "Billboard Blitz for 877-Why-Islam info hotline"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711000101/http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/08/15/billboard-blitz-for-877-why-islam/ |date=July 11, 2014 }}, ''CNN'', August 15, 2011</ref><ref>Alice Speri, [http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/08/nj_turnpike_muslim_billboard.html "In time for Ramadan, toll-free hotline seeks to educate N.J. residents about Islam"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812214530/http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/08/nj_turnpike_muslim_billboard.html |date=August 12, 2014 }}, ''The Star-Ledger'', August 8, 2011</ref>
The [[Islamic Supreme Council of America]] (ISCA) is a small organization representing [[Sufi]] teachings, which, according to adherents, is the inner, mystical dimension of Islam. The ISCA's stated aims include providing practical solutions for American Muslims, based on the traditional Islamic legal rulings of an international advisory board, many of whom are recognized as the highest ranking Islamic scholars in the world. ISCA strives to integrate traditional scholarship in resolving contemporary issues affecting the maintenance of Islamic beliefs in a modern, secular society.<ref name="islamicsupremecouncil.org"/> It has been linked to neoconservative thought.
[[File:RoxburyMosque2.JPG|thumb|[[Islamic Society of Boston]] mosque in Roxbury.]] [[File:Masjed UA.jpg|thumb|Tucson Islamic Center, [[Tucson, Arizona]].]] The [[Islamic Assembly of North America]] (IANA) is a leading Muslim organization in the United States. According to its website, among the goals of IANA is to "unify and coordinate the efforts of the different dawah oriented organizations in North America and guide or direct the Muslims of this land to adhere to the proper Islamic methodology." In order to achieve its goals, IANA uses a number of means and methods including conventions, general meetings, dawah-oriented institutions and academies, etc.<ref>[http://www.iananet.org Islamic Assembly of North America Official Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050606083407/http://www.iananet.org/ |date=June 6, 2005 }}.</ref> IANA folded in the aftermath of the attack of September 11, 2001 and they have reorganized under various banners such as Texas Dawah and the [[Almaghrib Institute]].
The [[Muslim Students' Association]] (MSA) is a group dedicated, by its own description, to Islamic societies on college campuses in Canada and the United States for the good of Muslim students. The MSA is involved in providing Muslims on various campuses the opportunity to practice their religion and to ease and facilitate such activities. MSA is also involved in social activities, such as fund raisers for the homeless during Ramadan. The founders of MSA would later establish the [[Islamic Society of North America]] and [[Islamic Circle of North America]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msa-natl.org |title=Muslim Student Association Official Website |publisher=Msa-natl.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104220018/http://www.msa-natl.org/ |archivedate=January 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The [[Islamic Information Center (IIC)]] (IIC) is a "grass-roots" organization that has been formed for the purpose of informing the public, mainly through the media, about the real image of Islam and Muslims. The IIC is run by chairman (Hojatul-Islam) Imam Syed Rafiq Naqvi, various committees, and supported by volunteers.<ref>[http://www.islamicinformationcenter.org Islamic Information Center Official Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061029054206/http://www.islamicinformationcenter.org/ |date=October 29, 2006 }}.</ref>
The [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]] was established in the U.S. in 1921, before the existence of [[Nation of Islam]], according to its members.<ref>{{cite web |author=Category: Misc |url=http://www.ahmadiyya.us/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=539&Itemid=238 |title=Official site |publisher=Ahmadiyya.us |date=November 5, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102113241/http://www.ahmadiyya.us/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=539&Itemid=238 |archivedate=November 2, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2010/05/21/naseem-mahdi-muhammad-cartoons-controversy-facebook-draw-bait/ |title=reference at end |publisher=Foxnews.com |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603172938/http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2010/05/21/naseem-mahdi-muhammad-cartoons-controversy-facebook-draw-bait/ |archivedate=June 3, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> This sect, however, is considered heretical by mainstream Muslims and not considered a part of the Ummah, or worldwide community of Muslims.
Muslim Congress is another National Muslim Organization. It is primarily a Social Welfare organization and runs many social projects, including Food Distribution to the homeless in their "No More Hunger" project and also provides Scholarship. It is under the leadership of Islamic Scholars.

CAIR presents itself as representing mainstream, moderate Islam, and has condemned acts of terrorism and has been working in collaboration with the White House on "issues of safety and foreign policy."<ref name="Multi1"/> [[Criticism of the Council on American-Islamic Relations|The group has been criticized]] for alleged links to [[Islamic terrorism]] and it has been designated as a terrorist group by the [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="wam.ae">{{cite news|url=http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates-international/1395272478814.html|title=UAE Cabinet approves list of designated terrorist organisations, groups|date=November 15, 2014|publisher=WAM Emirates News Agency|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224100916/http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates-international/1395272478814.html|archivedate=December 24, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * The [[Muslim Public Affairs Council]] (MPAC) is an American Muslim public service and policy organization headquartered in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] and with offices in [[Washington, D.C.]] MPAC was founded in 1988. The mission of MPAC "encompasses promoting an American Muslim identity, fostering an effective grassroots organization, and training a future generation of men and women to share our vision. MPAC also works to promote an accurate portrayal of Islam and Muslims in mass media and popular culture, educating the American public (both Muslim and non-Muslim) about Islam, building alliances with diverse communities and cultivating relationships with opinion- and decision-makers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpac.org|title=Home|publisher=MPAC|accessdate=March 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308155123/http://www.mpac.org/|archivedate=March 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * The [[American Islamic Congress]] is a small secular Muslim organization that promotes "[[religious pluralism]]". The lessons of our unprecedented experience of acceptance and success must be carefully considered by our community."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aicongress.org/principles.htm |title=The American Islamic Congress Statement Of Principles |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020806012513/http://aicongress.org/principles.htm |archivedate=August 6, 2002 |accessdate=July 2, 2014}}</ref> The AIC holds an annual essay writing competition, the [[Dream Deferred Essay Contest]], focusing on [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] in the [[Middle East]]. * The [[Free Muslims Coalition]] states it was created to "eliminate broad base support for Islamic extremism and terrorism" and to strengthen secular democratic institutions in the Middle East and the Muslim World by supporting Islamic reformation efforts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freemuslims.org/ |title=Free Muslims Coalition |publisher=Freemuslims.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612210342/http://www.freemuslims.org/ |archivedate=June 12, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Muslims for Bush]] was an [[advocacy group]] aiming to drum up support from Muslims for President [[George W. Bush]]. It was co-founded by Muhammad Ali Hasan and his mother Seeme, who were prominent donors to the Republican Party. In 2010, co-founder Muhammad Ali Hasan left the Republican Party. Muslims for Bush has since been reformed into the bipartisan [[Muslims for America]]. * [[American Muslim Political Action Committee]] (AMPAC) was created in July 2012 by MD Rabbi Alam, a Bangladeshi-born American politician.
