It is headquartered in Kansas City, Missouri, with two regional offices in New York City and Madison, Wisconsin. AMPAC a bipartisan political platform for Muslim Americans to participate in political races. AMPAC presents an Islamic perspective on issues of importance to the American public, and seeks to empower the American Muslim community and encourage its social and political activism. On September 11, 2013, AMPAC organized the [[Million Muslim March]] which took place at the National Mall in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Million-Muslim-March-Christian-Protesters-White-House-Sept-11-2013-223315411.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055142/http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Million-Muslim-March-Christian-Protesters-White-House-Sept-11-2013-223315411.html |archivedate=September 21, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} "Million Muslim March" Attendees Confronted by Christian Protesters on National Mall</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/11/million-muslim-march_n_3906303.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917091800/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/11/million-muslim-march_n_3906303.html |archivedate=September 17, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} 'Million Muslim March' Shaping Up To Be More Like A Few Hundred People Walking Down The Street: Kevin Barrett at the March Leading</ref> * The Islamic Center of [[Passaic County, New Jersey|Passaic County]], the American Arab Civic Organization, and the American Muslim Union, all based in [[Paterson, New Jersey|Paterson]], [[New Jersey]], voice Muslims' opposition to terrorism, including the [[November 2015 Paris attacks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/new-jersey-muslim-groups-condemn-paris-attacks-1.1455972|title=New Jersey Muslim groups condemn Paris attacks|author1=Linda Moss|author2=Minjae Park|publisher=North Jersey Media Group|date=November 16, 2015|accessdate=November 16, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117031605/http://www.northjersey.com/news/new-jersey-muslim-groups-condemn-paris-attacks-1.1455972|archivedate=November 17, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Charity=== Charitable donations within the Muslim American community are impacted by domestic political and social climates. ISPU found in 2017 that, “23% of Muslim Americans increased their giving to organizations associated with their faith community and 18% joined, donated to, or volunteered at a civic organizations for the first time as a result of the 2016 national elections.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ispu.org/american-muslim-poll-2017/|title=American Muslim Poll 2017 {{!}} ISPU|date=2017-03-21|work=Institute for Social Policy and Understanding|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
In addition to the organizations listed above, other Muslim organizations in the United States serve more specific needs. For example, some organizations focus almost exclusively on charity work. As a response to a crackdown on Muslim charity organizations working overseas such as the [[Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development|Holy Land Foundation]], more Muslims have begun to focus their charity efforts within the United States.
* [[Inner-City Muslim Action Network]] (IMAN) is one of the leading Muslim charity organizations in the United States. According to the Inner-City Muslim Action Network, IMAN seeks "to utilize the tremendous possibilities and opportunities that are present in the community to build a dynamic and vibrant alternative to the difficult conditions of inner city life." IMAN sees understanding Islam as part of a larger process to empower individuals and communities to work for the betterment of humanity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imancentral.org |title=Inner-City Muslim Action Network Official Website |publisher=Imancentral.org |date=December 1, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726173917/http://www.imancentral.org/ |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *[[Islamic Relief]] USA is the [[United States|American]] branch of [[Islamic Relief]] Worldwide, an international relief and development organization. Its stated goal is "to alleviate the suffering, hunger, illiteracy and diseases worldwide without regard to color, race or creed." They focus on development projects; emergency relief projects, such as providing aid to victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]]; orphans projects; and seasonal projects, such as food distributions during the month of [[Ramadan]]. They provide aid internationally and in the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irw.org |title=Islamic Relief Official Website |publisher=Irw.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810194309/http://www.irw.org/ |archivedate=August 10, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *[[Project Downtown]] is a non profit organization originated in Miami Fl. From what started as two men giving away a few sandwiches eventually turned into an array of chapters all over the United States giving away thousands of packets of food, hygiene bags, clothes, and other necessities of life to those who cannot afford it. The motto of Project Downtown is "We feed you for the sake of God alone, no reward do we seek, nor thanks." (Quran 76:9) *[[Compassionate Care Network, Chicago, CCNchicago]] was formed 14 years ago to offer basic health screening for the uninsured population in the community. It offers health screening for obesity, hypertension, diabetes and health awareness for the indigent people. It has formed a network of 200 providers and enrolled several thousand patients. In 2014 CCN's work was recognized with honors from the Governor of Illinois and also by President Obama at the White House. In 2015 CCN was invited to participate in White House policy recommendation discussions with the US Dept of Health and Human Services Office of Faith Based and Neighborhood Partnerships.
===Museums=== There are two museums dedicated to the history of Islamic culture in the U.S. and abroad. The [[International Museum of Muslim Cultures]] in Jackson, Mississippi opened in early 2001.<ref>Ann Walter Sieber,{{cite web |url=http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200601/mississippi.s.muslim.museum.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807043319/http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200601/mississippi.s.muslim.museum.htm |archivedate=August 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}, ''Saudi Aramco World'', January/February 2006</ref> [[America's Islamic Heritage Museum]] in Washington, DC opened on April 30, 2011.<ref>Arlene Borenstein, {{cite web |url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Islamic-Heritage-Museum-Opens-in-DC--126333533.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902084650/http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Islamic-Heritage-Museum-Opens-in-DC--126333533.html |archivedate=September 2, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}, ''NBC Washington'', July 28, 2011</ref>
===Research and think tanks=== The [[Institute for Social Policy and Understanding]], with offices in Dearborn, MI and Washington, DC, is an independent, nonpartisan research organization specializing in addressing the most pressing challenges facing the American Muslim community and in bridging the information gap between the American Muslim community and the wider society.
==Views== ===American populace's views on Islam=== A nationwide survey conducted in 2003 by the Pew Research Center and the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life reported that the percentage of Americans with an unfavorable view of Islam increased by one percentage point between 2002 and 2003 to 34%, and then by another two percentage points in 2005 to 36%. At the same time the percentage responding that Islam was more likely than other religion to encourage violence fell from 44% in July 2003 to 36% in July 2005.<ref name="PewLondon">[http://pewforum.org/uploadedfiles/Topics/Religious_Affiliation/Muslim/muslims-survey-2005.pdf Views of Muslim-Americans hold steady after London Bombings] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708105444/http://pewforum.org/uploadedfiles/Topics/Religious_Affiliation/Muslim/muslims-survey-2005.pdf |date=July 8, 2011 }} – [[Pew Research Center]]. July 26, 2005</ref>
{|class="wikitable" align="right" |- ! colspan=3 | July 2007 ''Newsweek'' survey of non-Muslim Americans<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/newsweek-poll-americans-are-mixed-on-us-muslims-52756242.html |title=NEWSWEEK Poll: Americans Are Mixed on U.S. Muslims |location=New York |publisher=Prnewswire.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114231917/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/newsweek-poll-americans-are-mixed-on-us-muslims-52756242.html |archivedate=January 14, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- | '''Statement''' | '''Agree''' | '''Disagree''' |- | Muslims in the United States are as <br>loyal to the U.S. as they are to Islam | 40% | 32% |- | Muslims do not condone violence | 63% | |- | Qur'an does not condone violence | 40% | 28% |- | Muslim culture does not glorify<br> suicide | | 41% |- | Concern about Islamic radicals | | 54% |- | Support wiretapping by FBI | | 52% |- | American Muslims more "peaceable"<br> than non-American ones | 52% | 7% |- | Muslims are unfairly targeted by<br> law enforcement | 38% | 52% |- | Oppose mass detentions of Muslims | 60% | 25% |- | Believe most are immigrants | | 52% |- | Would allow son or daughter to date<br> a Muslim | | 64% |- | Muslim students should be allowed<br> to wear headscarves | 69% | 23% |- | Would vote for a qualified Muslim<br> for political office | 45% | 45% |}
The July 2005 Pew survey also showed that 59% of American adults view Islam as "very different from their religion," down one percentage point from 2003. In the same survey 55% had a favorable opinion of Muslim Americans, up four percentage points from 51% in July 2003.<ref name="PewLondon"/> A December 2004 Cornell University survey shows that 47% of Americans believe that the Islamic religion is more likely than others to encourage violence among its believers.<ref>[http://www.comm.cornell.edu/msrg/report1a.pdf Restrictions on Civil Liberties, Views of Islam, & Muslim Americans] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104030901/http://www.comm.cornell.edu/msrg/report1a.pdf |date=January 4, 2006 }} – [[Cornell University]]. December 2005</ref>
A CBS April 2006 poll showed that, in terms of faiths<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/04/12/national/main1494697.shtml Poll news] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102132747/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/04/12/national/main1494697.shtml |date=November 2, 2013 }} [[CBS]].</ref> * 58% of Americans have favorable attitudes toward [[Protestantism]]/Other [[Christian]]s * 48% favorable toward [[Catholicism]] * 47% favorable toward [[Judaism]] * 31% favorable toward [[Fundamentalist Christianity|Christian fundamentalism]] * 20% favorable toward [[Mormonism]] * 19% favorable toward [[Islam]] * 8% favorable toward [[Scientology]]
The Pew survey shows that, in terms of adherents<ref name="PewLondon"/> * 77% of Americans have favorable opinions of [[Jew]]s * 73% favorable of [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholics]] * 57% favorable of "[[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christians]]" * 55% favorable of [[Muslim]]s * 35% favorable of [[Atheism|Atheists]]
A 2011 [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll found that 56% of Protestants, 63% of Catholics, and 70% of Jews believed that American Muslims had no sympathy for [[Al Qaeda]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2011/0802/Muslim-Americans-are-optimistic-despite-discrimination-new-poll-says/%28page%29/2 |title=Muslim Americans are optimistic despite discrimination, new poll says |work=The Christian Science Monitor |date=August 2, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022073423/http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2011/0802/Muslim-Americans-are-optimistic-despite-discrimination-new-poll-says/(page)/2 |archivedate=October 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A 2015 Brookings poll found that 14% Americans believe most Muslims support ISIS and another 44% believe Muslims partially support ISIS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/american-public-attitudes-toward-isis-and-syria/|title=American Public Attitudes Toward ISIS and Syria {{!}} Brookings Institution|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923184602/https://www.brookings.edu/research/american-public-attitudes-toward-isis-and-syria/|archivedate=September 23, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A 2016 poll found that on average; Americans believed that 17% of the US population was Muslim and that this number would rise to 23% by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ipsos-mori.com/Assets/Docs/Polls/ipsos-mori-perils-of-perception-charts-2016.pdf|title=Perils of Perception, A 40 Country Study|publisher=Ipsos Mori|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122010810/https://www.ipsos-mori.com/Assets/Docs/Polls/ipsos-mori-perils-of-perception-charts-2016.pdf|archivedate=January 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A 2018 poll by The Institute for Social Policy and Understanding found that 86% of Americans report wanting to, “live in a country where no one is targeted for their religious identity.”<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ispu.org/american-muslim-poll-2018-full-report/|title=American Muslim Poll 2018: Full Report {{!}} ISPU|date=2018-04-30|work=Institute for Social Policy and Understanding|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> 95% of American Jews and 78% of white Evangelicals agreed. The study also found that 66% of Americans agree that “the negative things politicians say regarding Muslims is harmful to our country.” Breaking down the results by faith community, 78% of Muslims and non-affiliated Americans agreed, contrasted with only 45% of white Evangelicals. Most Americans oppose banning the building of mosques (79%), the surveillance of U.S. mosques (63%), and the ‘Muslim Ban’ (~63%) pushed by the Trump Administration.<ref name=":2" /> Most Americans also take issue with the collective blaming of Muslims for the acts of individuals, and 69% of those surveyed believe Muslims are no more responsible for violence carried out by a Muslim than anyone else. ISPU writes that, “Though at a lower rate, the majority of Americans (55%) say that most Muslims living in the United States are committed to the well-being of America.” <ref name=":2" />
According to a research by the New America foundation and the American Muslim Initiative found in 2018,56 percent of Americans believed Islam was compatible with American values and 42 percent said it was not. About 60 percent believed US Muslims were as patriotic as others, while 38 percent they were not.The study also found that a big majority of Americans - 74 percent - accepted there was "a lot" of bigotry against Muslims existed.Researchers also found that Republicans were more likely to hold negative perceptions of Muslims with 71 percent.<ref>https://www.aljazeera.com/amp/news/2018/11/americans-islam-incompatible-values-181101185805274.html</ref>
===American Muslims' views of the United States=== {|class="wikitable" align="left" |- ! colspan=3 | PEW's poll of views on American Society<ref name="PewMainstream"/> |- | '''Statement''' | '''U.S.<br> Muslim''' | '''General<br> public''' |- | Agree that one can get<br> ahead with hard work | 71% | 64% |- | Rate their community as<br> "excellent" or "good" | 72% | 82% |- | Excellent or good<br> personal financial situation | 42% | 49% |- | Satisfied with the<br> state of the U.S. | 38% | 32% |} In a 2007 survey titled ''Muslim Americans: Middle Class and Mostly Mainstream'', the [[Pew Research Center]] found Muslim Americans to be "largely integrated, happy with their lives, and moderate with respect to many of the issues that have divided Muslims and Westerners around the world."<ref name="PewMainstream">{{cite web|url=http://pewresearch.org/assets/pdf/muslim-americans.pdf |title=''Muslim Americans: Middle Class and Mostly Mainstream'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916051122/http://pewresearch.org/assets/pdf/muslim-americans.pdf |archivedate=September 16, 2012 |df= }} {{small|(656 KB)}}, Pew Research Center, May 22, 2007</ref>
47% of respondents said they considered themselves Muslims first and Americans second. However, this was compared to 81% of British Muslims and 69% of German Muslims, when asked the equivalent question. A similar disparity exists in income, the percentage of American Muslims living in poverty is 2% higher than the general population, compared to an 18% disparity for French Muslims and 29% difference for Spanish Muslims.<ref name="PewMainstream"/>
Politically, American Muslims both supported larger government and are socially conservative. Despite their social conservatism, 71% of American Muslims expressed a preference for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref name="PewMainstream"/> The Pew Research survey also showed that nearly three quarters of respondents believed that American society rewards them for hard work regardless of their religious background.<ref>{{cite news | title=Major poll finds U.S. Muslims Mostly Mainstream | date=June 1, 2007 | publisher=Voice of America | url=http://voanews.com/english/archive/2007-06/2007-06-01-voa36.cfm | work=VOA News | pages= | accessdate=December 25, 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211132319/http://voanews.com/english/archive/2007-06/2007-06-01-voa36.cfm | archivedate=December 11, 2008 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The same poll also reported that 40% of U.S. Muslims believe that Arab Muslims carried out the 9/11 attacks. Another 28% do not believe it and 32% said they had no opinion. Among the 28% who doubted that Arab Muslims were behind the conspiracy, one-fourth said the U.S. government or President [[George W. Bush]] was responsible. 26% of American Muslims believe the U.S.-led "war on terror" is a sincere effort to root out international terrorism. 5% of those surveyed had a "very favorable" or "somewhat favorable" view of Al-Qaeda. 35% of American Muslims stated that the decision for military action in Afghanistan was the right one and 12% supported the use of military force in Iraq.<ref name="PewMainstream"/>
In 2011, a [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll found that 93% of Muslim Americans considered themselves loyal to the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsmax.com/US/gallup-muslim-americans-poll/2011/08/02/id/405835 |title=Gallup Poll: Most Muslim-Americans Loyal to US |publisher=Newsmax.com |date=August 2, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201230455/http://www.newsmax.com/US/gallup-muslim-americans-poll/2011/08/02/id/405835 |archivedate=December 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Although American Muslims do report feeling discriminated against as a religious minority, they are just as likely as the general public (81%) to say they value their American Identity. In fact, a 2018 study done by the Institute for Social Policy and Understanding asserts that, “a higher religious identity correlates with a higher American identity among all Americans, especially Muslims.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ispu.org/american-muslim-poll-2018-full-report/|title=American Muslim Poll 2018: Full Report {{!}} ISPU|date=2018-04-30|work=Institute for Social Policy and Understanding|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
===American Muslims' views on LGBT=== In a 2007 poll conducted by Pew Research Center, 27% of American Muslims believed that homosexuality should be accepted. In a 2011 poll, that percentage had risen to 39%. In a July 2017 poll, Muslims who say homosexuality should be accepted by society outnumber those who say it should be discouraged (52% of respondents, versus 33%).<ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2017/07/26/findings-from-pew-research-centers-2017-survey-of-us-muslims/</ref><ref>http://www.pewforum.org/2017/07/26/political-and-social-views/</ref>.According to research by [[Public Religion Research Institute|the Public Religion Research Institute’s]] 2017 American Values Atlas, 51% of American Muslims favor same-sex marriage, while 34% are opposed.<ref>https://www.prri.org/research/emerging-consensus-on-lgbt-issues-findings-from-the-2017-american-values-atlas/</ref>.
===American Muslim life after the September 11 attacks=== [[File:Bush Islamic Center Washington.jpg|thumb|President [[George W. Bush]] inside the [[Islamic Center of Washington]], D.C.]] [[File:Ground Zero Mosque Supporters 4.jpg|thumb|[[Muslim]] children in [[New York City]] supporting [[Park51]].]] After the [[September 11 attacks]], America saw an increase in the number of hate crimes committed against people who were perceived to be Muslim, particularly those of Middle Eastern and South Asian descent. More than 20 acts of discrimination and violence were documented in the post 9/11 era by the U.S. Department of Justice.<ref name="U.S. Department of Justice">{{cite web|title=Civil Rights Division Post-9/11 Enforcement and Outreach|url=http://www.justice.gov/crt/legalinfo/discrimupdate.php|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111164216/http://www.justice.gov/crt/legalinfo/discrimupdate.php|archivedate=November 11, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Some of these acts were against Muslims living in America. Other acts were against those accused of being Muslims, such as Sikhs, and people of Arabian and South-Asian backgrounds<ref name="U.S. Department of Justice"/> A publication in [[Journal of Applied Social Psychology]] found evidence that the number of anti-Muslim attacks in America in 2001 increased from 354 to 1,501 following 9/11.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Oswald | first1 = Debra L. | year = 2005 | title = Understanding Anti-Arab Reactions Post-9/11: The Role of Threats, Social Categories, and Personal Ideologies | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Social Psychology | volume = 35 | issue = 9| pages = 1775–1799 | doi = 10.1111/j.1559-1816.2005.tb02195.x }}</ref> The same year, the [[Arab American Institute]] reported an increase in anti-Muslim hate crimes ranging from discrimination and destruction of private property to violent threats and assaults, some of which resulted in deaths.<ref name="Arab American Institute 2001 report submitted to the United States Commission on Civil Rights (PDF)">{{cite web|url=http://www.humanitykingdom.com/library/general/arab-american.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926003130/http://www.humanitykingdom.com/library/general/arab-american.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 26, 2007 |title=Humanitykingdom.com |format=PDF |accessdate=December 6, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="New York Times: Slain Arab-American May Have Been Hate-Crime Victim">{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03EFDC153CF935A35753C1A9679C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=Slain Arab-American May Have Been Hate-Crime Victim | first=Evelyn | last=Nieves | date=October 6, 2001}}</ref><ref name="Media Monitor Network: Is There A Solution To Racism?">{{cite web |last=Siddiqui |first=Habib |url=http://usa.mediamonitors.net/content/view/full/12447/ |title=Home / Articles / Is there a solution to racism? – Media Monitors Network (MMN) |publisher=Usa.mediamonitors.net |date=January 8, 2005 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320170356/http://usa.mediamonitors.net/content/view/full/12447/ |archivedate=March 20, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In a 2007 survey, 53% of American Muslims reported that it was more difficult to be a Muslim after the 9/11 attacks. Asked to name the most important problem facing them, the options named by more than ten percent of American Muslims were discrimination (19%), being viewed as a terrorist (15%), public's ignorance about Islam (13%), and stereotyping (12%). 54% believe that the U.S. government's anti-terrorism activities single out Muslims. 76% of surveyed Muslim Americans stated that they are very or somewhat concerned about the rise of Islamic extremism around the world, while 61% express a similar concern about the possibility of Islamic extremism in the United States.<ref name="PewMainstream"/>
On a small number of occasions Muslim women who wore distinctive [[hijab]] were harassed, causing some Muslim women to stay at home, while others temporarily abandoned the practice. In November 2009 Amal Abusumayah, a mother of four young girls, had her hijab pulled following derogatory comments while grocery shopping.<ref name="The Huffington Post">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ahmed-rehab/hijab-case-why-bigoted-ba_b_368330.html |title=Ahmed Rehab: Hijab Case: Why Bigoted Battery Makes For A Hate Crime |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114004112/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ahmed-rehab/hijab-case-why-bigoted-ba_b_368330.html |archivedate=November 14, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2006, one California woman was shot dead as she walked her child to school; she was wearing a headscarf and relatives and Muslim leaders believe that the killing was religiously motivated.<ref name=autogenerated7>[http://www.tolerance.org/news/article_hate.jsp?id=278 Tolerance.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929171538/http://www.tolerance.org/news/article_hate.jsp?id=278 |date=September 29, 2006 }}: Violence against Arab and Muslim Americans: Alabama to Massachusetts</ref><ref name=autogenerated5>[http://www.tolerance.org/news/article_hate.jsp?id=412 Tolerance.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929173417/http://www.tolerance.org/news/article_hate.jsp?id=412 |date=September 29, 2006 }}: Violence against Arab and Muslim Americans: Michigan to Wisconsin</ref> While 51% of American Muslims express worry that women wearing hijab will be treated poorly, 44% of American Muslim women who always wear hijab express a similar concern.<ref name="PewMainstream"/>
In 2011, The Learning Channel (TLC) broadcast a television series, ''[[All-American Muslim]]'', depicting the lives of different American Muslims in Dearborn, Michigan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tlc.howstuffworks.com/tv/all-american-muslim/about-all-american-muslim.htm |title=All-American Muslim: All-American Muslim: TLC |publisher=Tlc.howstuffworks.com |date=October 18, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219054208/http://tlc.howstuffworks.com/tv/all-american-muslim/about-all-american-muslim.htm |archivedate=December 19, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Even 16 years after 9/11, studies show that 42% Muslim Americans report bullying of their children in school because of their faith. One in four bullying incidents involving muslims is rerouted to have involved a teacher or other school official. Policies regarding immigration and airport security have also impacted Muslim American Lives after 9/11, with Muslims being twice as likely as any other faith group surveyed to be stopped at the border for additional screening. 67% of Muslims who were stopped at a US border also reported that they were easily identifiable as a member of their faith group. The climate of the 2016 presidential election and the policies that followed have also affected the lives and sentiments of Muslims Americans when it comes to their own safety. Muslims and Jews are, “most likely to express fear for their personal safety or that of their family from white supremacist groups as a result of the 2016 elections.” Overall, the majority of nonwhite Muslims do report some level of race-based discrimination in the past year. When it comes to religious based discrimination, Muslim Americans as a whole were the most likely faith group to report it.
==Controversy== A 2011 [[Pew Research Center|Pew]] poll reported support for extremism among Muslim Americans is negligible. <ref name=Pew2NoSigns>{{cite web |title=Muslim Americans: No Signs of Growth in Alienation or Support for Extremism |url=http://www.people-press.org/2011/08/30/muslim-americans-no-signs-of-growth-in-alienation-or-support-for-extremism/ |website=Pew Research Center |accessdate=26 September 2018 |date=30 August 2011}}</ref> The poll indicated all segments of the Muslim American population were opposed to violence and to a correlation between support for suicide bombing and religiosity measures.<ref name=Pew2NoSigns/> A 2007 [[Pew Research Center|Pew]] poll reported that very few Muslim Americans (1%) supported [[suicide attack|suicide bombings]] against civilian targets in at least some circumstances, with 81% reporting that suicide bombings and other forms of violence against civilians are never justified.<ref name=Pew2NoSigns/> Favorable views towards Al Qaeda were held by a comparably smaller percentage among Muslim Americans, 2% very favorable and 3% somewhat favorable.<ref name=Pew2NoSigns/> 15% of American Muslims under the age of 30 supported [[suicide attack|suicide bombings]] against civilian targets in at least some circumstances, on the other hand, 11% said it could be "rarely justified" in a 2007 Pew poll. Among those over the age of 30, just 6% expressed their support for the same. (9% of Muslims over 30 and 5% under 30 chose not to answer).<ref name="PewMainstream"/> [[File:US Muslim opinions on suicide bombing (2011).png|thumb|350px|Based on data from a 2011 poll by the [[Pew Research Center]], this graph records the distribution of feelings of U.S. Muslims on the topic of [[suicide bombings]].]] Terrorism that involved Muslim perpetrators began in the United States with the [[1993 shootings at CIA Headquarters]] in [[Langley, Virginia]], followed by the [[1993 World Trade Center bombing]] in New York City. After the [[September 11 attacks]] and the start of the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan war]] in 2001, there was concern about the potential radicalization of American Muslims.
Between 2001 and the end of 2009, there were 46 publicly reported incidents of "domestic radicalization and recruitment to jihadist terrorism" that involved at least 125 people between 2001 and the end of 2009. There had been an average of six cases per year since 2001, but that rose to 13 in 2009.<ref name="CFR">{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/terrorism/threat-homegrown-islamist-terrorism/p11509#p1 |title=Threat of Homegrown Islamist Terrorism |publisher=Cfr.org |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129212459/http://www.cfr.org/terrorism/threat-homegrown-islamist-terrorism/p11509#p1 |archivedate=November 29, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
While the seeming increase in cases may be alarming, half "involve single individuals, while the rest represent ‘tiny conspiracies,’ " according to Congressional testimony.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jenkins | first1 = Brian Michael |year=2010| title = No Path to Glory: Deterring Homegrown Terrorism | journal = [[RAND Corporation]] }}</ref> Furthermore, a 2012 study by the [[University of North Carolina]] indicated that the yearly number of cases of alleged plots by Muslim-Americans appears to be declining. The total of 20 indictments for terrorism in 2011 is down from 26 in 2010 and 47 in 2009 (the total since 9/11 is 193). The number of Muslim-Americans indicted for support of terrorism also fell, from 27 individuals in 2010 to just eight in 2011 (the total since 9/11 stands at 462).<ref name="jr-tcth">{{cite news | url=http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/muslim-american-terrorism-decade-since-911/ | title=Muslim-American Terrorism in the Decade Since 9/11 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426190112/http://journalistsresource.org/studies/government/criminal-justice/muslim-american-terrorism-decade-since-911/ | archivedate=April 26, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} JournalistsResource.org, retrieved March 20, 2012</ref><ref name="tcth">{{cite journal | last1 = Kurzman | first1 = Charles |year=2012| title = Muslim-American Terrorism in the Decade Since 9/11 | journal = Triangle Center on Terrorism and Homeland Security }}</ref> Also in apparent decline is the number of actual attacks: Of the 20 suspects indicted for terrorism, only one was charged with carrying out a terrorist act. This number is down from the six individuals charged with attacks in 2010.<ref name="tcth"/>
Muslim Americans are significantly represented among those who tip authorities off to alleged plots having given 52 of the 140 documented tips regarding individuals involved in violent terrorist plots since 9/11.<ref name="jr-tcth"/><ref name="tcth"/>
The [[Boston Marathon bombing]] in 2013 caused 280 injuries, and 5 civilian and police deaths.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dzhokhar Tsarnaev: Boston Marathon bomber found guilty|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-32225787|accessdate=April 8, 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=April 8, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408184602/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-32225787|archivedate=April 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Attempted attacks, like the [[Curtis Culwell Center attack]] and [[2015 Boston beheading plot]] have attracted substantial media coverage<ref name="cbslocal">{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/03/breaking-shooting-in-garland|title=BREAKING: Shooting At Muhammad Art Exhibit In Garland « CBS Dallas/Fort Worth|publisher=dfw.cbslocal.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504134407/http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/03/breaking-shooting-in-garland/|archivedate=May 4, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and inflamed community relations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/29/us/mohammed-cartoon-contest/|title=Mohammed cartoon contest: Protest held outside Phoenix mosque|date=May 30, 2015|work=CNN|author=Sara Sidner|author2=Ed Payne|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530155932/http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/29/us/mohammed-cartoon-contest/|archivedate=May 30, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2015 the [[New America Foundation]] released information about violent extremist groups in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newamerica.org/in-depth/terrorism-in-america/what-threat-united-states-today/#americas-layered-defenses|title=Part IV. What is the Threat to the United States Today?|work=newamerica.org|accessdate=December 17, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219190255/http://www.newamerica.org/in-depth/terrorism-in-america/what-threat-united-states-today/#americas-layered-defenses|archivedate=December 19, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> While the Boston Marathon bombing had a high injury toll, only four deaths were counted by the group, and the group's count of only deaths from [[violent extremism]] showed that since 9/11, 48 people had been killed by anti-government extremists, compared to 28 by Jihadists.
Some Muslim Americans have been criticized because of perceived conflicts between their religious beliefs and mainstream American [[value system]]s. Muslim cab drivers in Minneapolis, Minnesota have been criticized for refusing passengers for carrying alcoholic beverages or dogs. The [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport]] authority has threatened to revoke the operating authority of any driver caught discriminating in this manner.<ref>{{cite news |title=Minnesota's Muslim cab drivers face crackdown |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSN1633289220070417?feedType=RSS |work= |publisher=Reuters |date=April 17, 2007 |accessdate=May 6, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509111033/http://www.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSN1633289220070417?feedType=RSS |archivedate=May 9, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> There are reported incidents in which Muslim cashiers have refused to sell pork products to their clientele.<ref>{{cite news |title=Target shifts Muslims who won’t ring up pork products |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17665989/ |work= |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=March 17, 2007 |accessdate=June 3, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322194421/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17665989 |archivedate=March 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ===Islamic extremism in the United States=== {{main|Jihadist extremism in the United States}} [[File:Stonewall Inn 15 pride weekend 2016.jpg|thumb|A memorial for the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]]]] At least one American not of recent immigrant background, [[John Walker Lindh]], has been imprisoned, convicted on charges of working with the [[Taliban]] and carrying weapons against American soldiers. He had converted to Islam while in the United States, moved to [[Yemen]] to study [[Arabic language|Arabic]], and then went to [[Pakistan]], where he was recruited by the Taliban.
Another American that was not of recent immigrant background, [[José Padilla (prisoner)|José Padilla]], of Puerto Rican descent and the first Hispanic-American to be imprisoned and convicted on suspicion of plotting a radiological bomb ("dirty bomb") attack. He was detained as a material witness until June 9, 2002, when President George W. Bush designated him an enemy combatant and, arguing that he was not entitled to trial in civilian courts, had him transferred to a military prison. He had converted to Islam while serving his last jail sentence in prison, and went to [[Pakistan]] where he was recruited into Al-Qaeda.
In 2015 four U.S. Marines were killed and three injured in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]] by a twenty four-year-old Kuwaiti man,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jul/16/chattanooga-shooting-mohammod-youssuf-abdulazeez|title=Mohammad Youssuf Abdulazeez: everything we know about the Chattanooga gunman|first1=Amanda|last1=Holpuch|first2=Alan|last2=Yuhas|date=July 17, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=December 17, 2016|via=The Guardian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221122400/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jul/16/chattanooga-shooting-mohammod-youssuf-abdulazeez|archivedate=December 21, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> a naturalized US citizen with an engineering degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chattanooga-shooter-came-from-middle-class-muslim-family/2015/07/16/815c39c2-2c04-11e5-bd33-395c05608059_story.html|title=Chattanooga gunman came from a middle-class Muslim family|work=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=December 17, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102115824/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chattanooga-shooter-came-from-middle-class-muslim-family/2015/07/16/815c39c2-2c04-11e5-bd33-395c05608059_story.html|archivedate=January 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Islamophobia=== {{main|Islamophobia in the United States}} [[File:March Against Sharia in Raleigh (36978805695).jpg|thumb|right|An anti-[[Sharia]] protest in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], 10 June 2017]] According to a 2011 Gallup poll, over the preceding decade there had been an increase in [[Islamophobia]], which it defined as "an exaggerated fear, hatred, and hostility toward Islam and Muslims that is perpetuated by negative stereotypes resulting in bias, discrimination, and the marginalization and exclusion of Muslims from social, political, and civic life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/157082/islamophobia-understanding-anti-muslim-sentiment-west.aspx|title=Islamophobia: Understanding Anti-Muslim Sentiment in the West|publisher=Gallup, Inc.|accessdate=March 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227054910/http://www.gallup.com/poll/157082/islamophobia-understanding-anti-muslim-sentiment-west.aspx|archivedate=February 27, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Another 2011 poll provided by ''[[The Washington Post]]''<ref>{{cite news|title=What most Americans think of Islam today|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/11/17/most-americans-say-islam-is-at-odds-with-american-values/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=November 17, 2015|access-date=December 12, 2015|issn=0190-8286|language=en-US|first=Christopher|last=Ingraham|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151214200216/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/11/17/most-americans-say-islam-is-at-odds-with-american-values/|archivedate=December 14, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> through the [[Public Religion Research Institute]] states that 48 percent of Americans are uncomfortable with Muslim women wearing the burqa. A 2014 [[Pew Research Center]] survey found that Muslims were the most disliked religious group in the United States with an average "cold" rating of 40 (out of 100), which is lower than the 41 cold rating received by atheists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2014/07/16/how-americans-feel-about-religious-groups/|title=How Americans Feel About Religious Groups: Jews, Catholics & Evangelicals Rated Warmly, Atheists and Muslims More Coldly|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=July 16, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170209101432/http://www.pewforum.org/2014/07/16/how-americans-feel-about-religious-groups/|archivedate=February 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to a poll in November 2015 by the [[Public Religion Research Institute]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Survey {{!}} Anxiety, Nostalgia, and Mistrust: Findings from the 2015 American Values Survey|url=http://publicreligion.org/research/2015/11/survey-anxiety-nostalgia-and-mistrust-findings-from-the-2015-american-values-survey/#.VmtqM_mrShc|publisher=Public Religion Research Institute|accessdate=December 12, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210212619/http://publicreligion.org/research/2015/11/survey-anxiety-nostalgia-and-mistrust-findings-from-the-2015-american-values-survey/#.VmtqM_mrShc|archivedate=December 10, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> 56 percent of Americans believe that the values of Islam are at odds with the American values and ways of life.
Public institutions in the U.S. have also drawn fire for accommodating Islam at the expense of taxpayers. The [[University of Michigan–Dearborn]] and a public college in Minnesota have been criticized for accommodating Islamic prayer rituals by constructing footbaths for Muslim students using tax-payers' money. Critics said this special accommodation, which is made to satisfy the needs of Muslims alone, is a violation of Constitutional provisions [[separation of church and state in the United States|separating church and state]].<ref>[http://www.startribune.com/kersten/story/1115081.html Startribune.com] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Along the same constitutional lines, a San Diego public elementary school is being criticized for making special accommodations, specifically for American Muslims, by adding Arabic to its curriculum and giving breaks for Muslim prayers. Some critics said exceptions have not been made for any religious group in the past, and they see this as an endorsement of Islam.<ref>{{cite web |last=Gao |first=Helen |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20070702/news_1n2prayer.html |title=Muslim prayers in school debated |work=The San Diego Union-Tribune |date=July 2, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201180513/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20070702/news_1n2prayer.html |archivedate=December 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The first American Muslim Congressman, [[Keith Ellison (politician)|Keith Ellison]], created controversy when he compared President George W. Bush's actions after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] to [[Adolf Hitler]]'s actions after the Nazi-sparked [[Reichstag fire]], saying that Bush was exploiting the aftermath of 9/11 for political gain, as Hitler had exploited the Reichstag fire to suspend constitutional liberties.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/07/14/wbush114.xml Bush like Hitler, says first Muslim in Congress] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080224114527/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F07%2F14%2Fwbush114.xml |date=February 24, 2008 }} ''The Telegraph''</ref> The [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] and the [[Anti-Defamation League]] condemned Ellison's remarks. The congressman later retracted the statement, saying that it was "inappropriate" for him to have made the comparison.<ref name="APerror">[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/07/18/politics/main3069391.shtml Congressman Admits 9/11 Error] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014032312/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/07/18/politics/main3069391.shtml |date=October 14, 2007 }}, Associated Press, July 18, 2007</ref>
At Columbus Manor School, a suburban [[Chicago]] [[elementary school]] with a student body nearly half Muslim [[Arab American]], school board officials have considered eliminating holiday celebrations after Muslim parents complained that their culture's holidays were not included. Local parent Elizabeth Zahdan said broader inclusion, not elimination, was the group's goal. "I only wanted them modified to represent everyone," the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' quoted her as saying. "Now the kids are not being educated about other people."<ref>[http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/578734,CST-NWS-oaklawn28.article Sun Times] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010050554/http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/578734,CST-NWS-oaklawn28.article |date=October 10, 2007 }} Retrieved in 2008.</ref> However, the district's superintendent, Tom Smyth, said too much school time was being taken to celebrate holidays already, and he sent a directive to his principals requesting that they "tone down" activities unrelated to the curriculum, such as holiday parties.

{{Infobox artwork | title = Jefferson Davis | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | wikidata = | image = Jefferson Davis Statue by Pompeo Coppini.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = The statue in the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History, 2018 | artist = [[Pompeo Coppini]] | year = {{start date|1933}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | catalogue = | medium = Bronze | movement = | subject = [[Jefferson Davis]] | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = 102 | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | weight = | designation = | condition = | museum = [[Dolph Briscoe Center for American History]] | city = [[Austin, Texas]], United States | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = [[University of Texas at Austin]] | accession = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | module = | website = }} '''''Jefferson Davis''''' is a statue depicting the [[Jefferson Davis|American-Confederate politician of the same name]] by [[Pompeo Coppini]]. The sculpture was commissioned in 1919 by [[George W. Littlefield]] to be included in the [[Littlefield Fountain]] on the campus of the [[University of Texas at Austin]]. It was installed on the university's South Mall from 1933 to 2015, when it was relocated to the [[Dolph Briscoe Center for American History]] in [[Austin, Texas]].
==History== {{Further|Littlefield Fountain}} In 1919, University of Texas regent [[George W. Littlefield]] donated funds to pay for the construction of a "Memorial Gateway" at the south entrance to the university's campus that would honor the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] dead from the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. He hired [[San Antonio]]-based Italian-born sculptor [[Pompeo Coppini]] to design the monument, which was to include a number of statues of notable figures from the history of Texas and the American South. The memorial was ultimately redesigned as the [[Littlefield Fountain]] and instead dedicated to the university's students and alumni who had died in the Great War (now known as [[World War I]]).<ref name="Nicar2001">{{cite journal|author1=Jim Nicar|title=Symbolism Amok|journal=[[The Alcalde]]|date=May 2001|volume=89|issue=5|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xs0DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80|publisher=Emmis Communications|accessdate=November 29, 2017}}</ref>
As part of the memorial project, in the 1920s Coppini sculpted bronze statues of [[Jefferson Davis]] and five other Texan and Confederate notables selected by Littlefield, which he intended to display around the fountain. However, as construction on the memorial proceeded in the early 1930s, campus architect [[Paul Cret]] decided to instead install the six statues along the university's South Mall, where they were placed in 1933 as the construction of the fountain complex was completed.<ref name="Nicar2001"/>
===Controversy and relocation=== {{Further|Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials}} Beginning in 2015 and accelerating in 2017, a national controversy grew over the prominent positions of monuments and memorials to the Confederacy in many public spaces across the United States, and particularly in the American South.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/08/16/us/confederate-monuments-removed.html|title=Confederate Monuments Are Coming Down Across the United States|first=Chris|last=Kenning|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 15, 2017|accessdate=November 29, 2017}}</ref> In this context, the statues of Confederate notables along the university's South Mall that Coppini had designed for the Littlefield Fountain attracted increased public criticism.
In March 2015, UT's student government passed a resolution calling for the removal of ''Jefferson Davis'' from the South Mall.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Written in Stone: History of racism lives on in UT monuments|newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|first=Mac|last=McCann|date=May 29, 2015|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2015-05-29/written-in-stone/|accessdate=November 29, 2017}}</ref> That August, the university in fact removed the statues of both Davis and [[Woodrow Wilson]] from the Mall and placed them in storage, despite a lawsuit from the Texas Division of the [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]], which failed to persuade the [[Texas Supreme Court]] to block the plan.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Crews remove Jefferson Davis, Woodrow Wilson statues from UT Main Mall|newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|first=Ralph K.M.|last=Haurwitz|date=August 30, 2015|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/crews-remove-jefferson-davis-woodrow-wilson-statues-from-main-mall/5uZnpjAnISv0YtFSnHreTL/|accessdate=November 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/08/30/436072805/jefferson-davis-statue-comes-down-at-university-of-texas|title=Jefferson Davis Statue Comes Down at University of Texas|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref> ''Davis'' was later relocated to the university's [[Dolph Briscoe Center for American History]], where it has been displayed since 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/commentary/2017/04/07/jefferson-davis-statue-returns-university-texas|title=Jefferson Davis statue returns to University of Texas|date=7 April 2017|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|accessdate=July 31, 2017|publisher=[[A. H. Belo]]|issn=1553-846X}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/the-daily-post/jefferson-davis-back-ut/|title=Jefferson Davis is Back at UT|date=17 April 2017|work=[[Texas Monthly]]|accessdate=July 31, 2017|location=Austin, Texas|issn=0148-7736}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Good article}} {{Multi-word family name|Ganz Cooney|Cooney}} {{Infobox person | image = Joan Ganz Cooney.JPG | caption = Cooney in 1985 | birth_name = Joan Ganz | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1929|11|30}} | birth_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Arizona]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Television producer]] | known_for = Children's Television Workshop (1968-2000), [[Sesame Workshop]] (2000–present), ''[[Sesame Street]]'' (1969–present) | spouse = {{marriage|Tim Cooney|1964|1975|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|[[Peter George Peterson|Peter G. Peterson]]|1980|2018|reason=his death}} | alma_mater = [[University of Arizona]] (B.A., Education, 1951) }} '''Joan Ganz Cooney''' (born '''Joan Ganz'''; November 30, 1929{{Cite web |url=http://joanganzcooneycenter.org/about-us/legacy/ |title=Our Legacy |website=Joan Ganz Cooney Center |language=en-US |access-date=November 29, 2018 }}) is an American television producer. She is one of the founders of [[Sesame Workshop]] (originally ''Children's Television Workshop'' or CTW), the organization famous for the creation of the [[Children's television series|children's television show]] ''[[Sesame Street]]'', which was also co-created by her. Ganz Cooney grew up in Phoenix, Arizona and earned a B.A. degree in education from the [[University of Arizona]] in 1951. After working for the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] in Washington, D.C. and as a journalist in Phoenix, she worked as a publicist for television and production companies in New York City. In 1961, she became interested in working for educational television, and became a documentary producer for New York's first educational TV station [[WNET]] (Channel 13). Many of the programs she produced won local Emmys. In 1966, Ganz Cooney hosted what she called "a little dinner party" at her apartment near [[Gramercy Park]]. In attendance was her then-husband Tim Cooney, her boss Lewis Freedman, and [[Lloyd Morrisett]], an executive at the [[Carnegie Corporation]], in which the potential of television to teach young children was discussed. Ganz Cooney was chosen to oversee and direct the creation of what eventually became the children's television program ''Sesame Street'', which premiered in 1969, and the CTW, the organization that oversaw its production. Ganz Cooney was named CTW's first executive director. As one of the first female executives in American television, her appointment was called "one of the most important television developments of the decade". Ganz Cooney remained executive director of the CTW until 1990, when she became the chair of CTW's executive board. She served on several boards, was the trustees of many organizations, and received many awards and honorary degrees. In 2007, the Sesame Workshop founded [[The Joan Ganz Cooney Center]], named in her honor. ==Early life and education== Joan Ganz was born on November 30, 1929, in Phoenix, Arizona, to Sylvan Ganz, a banker, and Pauline (née Reddon), a homemaker. Her father was a native [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenician]] who was born in the U.S. so that his mother could receive medical care after his birth. Her grandfather [[Emil Ganz]] was a tailor from [[Walldorf, Thuringia]], in Germany, who immigrated to the U.S. in 1858 and was president of the First National Bank of Arizona and mayor of Phoenix for three terms. Joan Ganz was the youngest of three siblings. She described her childhood as "upper middle class, country club atmosphere" and stated, "I was raised in the most conventional way, raised to be a housewife and a mother, to work an interesting job when I got out of college, and to marry at the appropriate age, which would have been twenty-five". Her father was Jewish and her mother was Catholic.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19850716&id=8rkxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k-UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5515,3320603] She attended [[North High School (Phoenix, Arizona)|North High School]] in Phoenix, where she was active in school plays. She stated that her biggest influence as a teenager was her teacher Bud Brown, whose lectures about the [[civil rights movement]], poverty, the free press, and [[antisemitism]] in Europe "absolutely inflamed" her and changed her life. Brown was later investigated as a [[Communist]]. She went to [[Dominican University of California|Dominican College]], an all-girls Catholic institution in [[San Rafael, California]] for a year before transferring to the [[University of Arizona]] in 1948. She stopped acting in college because her father refused to support her in that career. She chose education, even though she was not interested in becoming a teacher, on the recommendation of her mother and because as she later stated, "It was something that girls of my generation did because teaching was acceptable". ==Early career== After graduating in 1951, Ganz Cooney moved to [[Washington, D.C.]], where she worked as a clerk and typist at the [[United States Department of State|State Department]]. She was exposed to Father [[James Keller|James Keller's]] [[The Christophers|Christopher Movement]], which inspired her to become involved with television and the media. Ganz Cooney later said, "Father Keller said that if idealists didn't go into the media, nonidealists would". She returned to Phoenix and despite no experience in [[journalism]], took a job as a reporter at the ''[[Arizona Republic]]''. Eighteen months later, in 1953 and at the age of 23, she moved to New York City and was a [[public relations|publicist]] for the next ten years, initially for [[David Sarnoff]] at [[RCA]], then at [[NBC]] writing [[press release]]s and [[soap opera]] synopses, and then for the ''[[United States Steel Hour]]'' at [[CBS]]. During this time, she became involved with liberal [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] politics and "fell in with a literary set of young writers and editors who gathered at the West Side apartment of ''[[Partisan Review]]'' editor [[William Phillips (editor)|William Phillips]]". Some of this "notable group" included [[Jason Epstein]] and [[Norman Mailer]]. In 1956, after many years of depression, Ganz Cooney's father committed suicide at his home in Phoenix. {{quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align = right |bgcolor = #c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quote = Her literary contacts, political savvy, and vast interest in the "world of ideas"—in addition to disarming self-confidence—got her hired [at Channel 13]. Her masterful organization skills and intuitive grasp of the zeitgeist of the times won her success. |salign = right |source = —Writer Louise A. Gikow, ''Sesame Street: A Celebration'' }} While Ganz Cooney was working for the ''U.S. Steel Hour'', a colleague left to work for the educational television station [[WGBH-TV]] in Boston; her reaction was life-changing: "What?! There is educational television?!" She later stated, "I knew that I was born to be in educational television; it was [[Conversion of Paul the Apostle|St. Paul on the highway]]". In 1961, she began to track the progress of a court case in which a New York City nonprofit group was attempting to acquire [[Newark, New Jersey]]-based [[Independent station (North America)|independent station]] WNTA-TV (channel 13), which would become the precursor of [[PBS]] station [[WNET]], the first public television station in the New York area. When channel 13 became [[noncommercial educational|non-commercial]] two years later as WNDT, Ganz Cooney applied for a position as the station's publicist, but the general manager told her they needed producers. "I can produce", she told him, even though she had no experience in producing television shows. She later stated, "I've never been qualified for any job I've been hired for". According to television historian Cary O'Dell, WNDT hired her because of the ties she had made through her political activities and associations with ''Partisan Review''. Ganz Cooney later said during an interview with the [[Archive of American Television]] that the transition to becoming a documentary producer was not difficult for her because she was well-read and aware of the issues of the day, adding, "I felt like I'd died and gone to heaven, dealing with foreign policy and domestic policy and civil rights, which became the great passion in those years for me". Taking a pay cut, Ganz Cooney and her boss Lewis Freedman produced what author Michael Davis called "a series of [[teach-in]]s on major issues". One of her first programs was called ''Court of Reason'', a weekly live debate show; notable guests included [[Malcolm X]] and [[Calvin Butts]]. She produced a debate show on America's policy about Cuba that aired the week before the [[Cuban Missile Crisis]]. She also produced another debate show called ''Poverty, Anti-Poverty, and the World'', in which poor people were brought into the studio to confront the government officials responsible for developing [[poverty reduction|anti-poverty program]]s. Although the ratings were low, Ganz Cooney and Freedman won [[Emmy Award|Emmys]] for its production, and as Davis stated, "the viewers who did tune in were serious-minded adults who cared about matters of race, injustice, and the imbalance of opportunity in New York and beyond". She also produced inexpensively-made documentaries that she later called "Little [[Grandma Moses]] documentaries" for WNDT that were well received by their viewers, including ''A Chance at the Beginning'', which featured the precursor of [[Head Start Program|Head Start]] that won her a local Emmy and was later used to train Head Start teachers. She later reported that WNDT had won eight out of 13 New York Emmys in one year. In February 1964, at age 34, she married Timothy Cooney, a staff member of New York mayor [[Robert Wagner, Jr.]] They met while she was working on ''A Chance at the Beginning''. He was also director of public relations for the New York City Department of Labor and director of New York's Office of Civil Defense. Timothy Cooney would eventually become "an unpaid advocate for the urban poor". Ganz Cooney credited him, whom Davis called "a radical feminist", for making her into a feminist, and later said that he was very supportive and encouraging. Davis called the Cooneys "a delightfully unmatched set, a [[Spencer Tracy]] and [[Katharine Hepburn]] twosome who married despite differences in upbringing, station, and sobriety". [[File:Joan Ganz Cooney portrait by ©Lynn Gilbert 1977.jpg|thumb|Joan Ganz Cooney, in her apartment, portrait by [[Lynn Gilbert]], 1977, New York]] ==''Sesame Street'' and the Children's Television Workshop== In the winter of 1966, Ganz Cooney hosted what she called "a little dinner party" at her apartment near [[Gramercy Park]]. In attendance was her husband, her boss Lewis Freedman, and Lloyd and Mary Morrisett, whom the Cooneys knew socially. [[Lloyd Morrisett]] was a mid-level executive at [[Carnegie Corporation]] (who later became its CEO), and was then responsible for funding educational research. The conversation turned to the possibilities of using television to educate young children; Morrisett raised the question, "Do you think television could be used to teach young children?" Ganz Cooney replied, "I don't know, but I'd like to talk about it." According to Davis, the party was the start of a five-decade long professional relationship between Ganz Cooney and Morrisett. A week later, Ganz Cooney and Freedman met with Morrisett at the offices of Carnegie Corporation to discuss doing a feasibility study on creating an educational television program for preschoolers. Freedman was opposed to Ganz Cooney's involvement because he did not think she would be interested in a project that focused on children and because he did not want to lose her at WNDT, but she was chosen to do the study. In the summer of 1967, Ganz Cooney took a leave of absence from WNDT and, funded by Carnegie Corporation, traveled the U.S. and Canada interviewing experts in child development, education, and television. She reported her findings in a fifty-five-page document entitled "The Potential Uses of Television in Preschool Education". The report, which Gikow called "a schematic for the show ''Sesame Street'' would become", described what the new show would look like and proposed the creation of a company that oversaw its production, which eventually became known as the [[Children's Television Workshop]] (CTW).In 2000, the CTW [http://www.muppetcentral.com/news/2000/060500.shtml changed its name to Sesame Workshop (SW).] Ganz Cooney later stated that her undergraduate training in Education helped her research and write the study, and that it, along with her Emmy, provided her with credibility in the eyes of both the experts she interviewed and the new show's funding sources. Davis credited Ganz Cooney's motivation to be involved with the project with her journalism skills, learned early in her career, and her idealism, which drove her to want to, as she put it, "make a difference". She later told an interviewer, "I could do a thousand documentaries on poverty and poor people that would be watched by a handful of the convinced, but I was never really going to have an influence on my times". She later told Davis, "Preschoolers were not necessarily my thing. It was using television in a constructive way that turned me on". At first, Ganz Cooney assumed that the project would be produced by WNDT, but when the station's owner rejected the proposal and questioned Ganz Cooney's credentials, she left the station and went to the Carnegie Corporation as a full-time consultant in May 1967. For the next two years, Ganz Cooney and Morrisett worked on researching and developing the new show, raising $8 million for ''Sesame Street'', and establishing the CTW. According to Davis, despite her leadership in the project's initial research and development, Ganz Cooney's installment as CTW's executive director was put in doubt due to her lack of high-level managerial experience and leadership, untested financial management skills, and lack of experience in children's television and education. Davis also speculated that sexism was involved, stating, "Doubters also questioned whether a woman could gain the full confidence of a quorum of men from the federal government and two elite philanthropies, institutions whose wealth exceeded the gross national product of entire countries". At first, Ganz Cooney did not fight for the position, but with the support of her husband and Morrisett, and after the investors of the project realized that they could not move forward without her, Ganz Cooney pursued it and was named executive director of CTW in February 1968. As one of the first female executives in American television, her appointment was called "one of the most important television developments of the decade". ''Sesame Street'' premiered on PBS on November 10, 1969.{{cite book|last=Mitgang|first=Lee D.|title=Big Bird and Beyond: The New Media and the Markle Foundation|year=2000|publisher=Fordham University Press|location=Bronx NY|isbn=0823220419|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kbI8kJqBM5oC&pg=PA17&dq=November+10,+1969+sesame&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BZTYUOvSIsLg2QWnxYHoCw&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=November%2010%2C%201969%20sesame&f=false|accessdate=December 24, 2012|page=17}} In its first season, the show won three Emmys, a [[Peabody Award|Peabody]], and was featured on the cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine.{{cite web|title=Sesame Street: TV's gift to children|url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19701123,00.html|work=TIME Magazine|accessdate=December 24, 2012|date=November 23, 1970}} According to ''[[Newsday]]'', "Scores of glowing newspaper and magazine stories fluttered down on Mrs. Cooney and her workshop like confetti onto the heads of conquering heroes". Les Brown of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called Ganz Cooney "St. Joan". Ganz Cooney later reported, "The reception was so incredible. The press adored us; the parents adored us." The first year ''Sesame Street'' was on the air, Ganz Cooney was, as Davis put it, "inundated with attention". Ganz Cooney reported that the requests for interviews from the press "were endless", and attributed it to the emergence of the women's movement in the early 1970s. Ganz Cooney also testified before Congressional hearings on children and television, starting before the show's premiere. In 1969, the Cooneys, who were childless, became "''de facto'' foster parents to an inner-city black child" whom Tim met while working in Harlem for a civil rights organization. Eventually, the child returned to live with his mother and was killed in New York City before he turned 30. The Cooneys' marriage, which Davis called "turbulent", ended in 1975. Due to Tim's long history of alcoholism, he was unable to support himself, so Ganz Cooney paid him [[alimony]] until his death in 1999. In August 1975, nine months after separating from her husband, Ganz Cooney was diagnosed with breast cancer and underwent a radical [[mastectomy]]. In 1980, Ganz Cooney married businessman [[Peter G. Peterson]], former [[U.S. Secretary of Commerce]] under President [[Richard Nixon]]. They met when Peterson was on the board of [[National Educational Television]], during her presentation of ''Sesame Street'' to them. From her marriage to Peterson, she has five stepchildren. ==Later years== Ganz Cooney remained the chairman and chief executive officer of the CTW until 1990, when she stepped down and was replaced by David Britt, whom Ganz Cooney called her "right-hand for many years". Britt had worked for her at the CTW since 1975 and had been its president and chief operating officer since 1988. At that time, she became chairman of the CTW's executive board, which oversaw its businesses and licensing, and became more involved in the organization's creative side. Cooney served on several committees and corporate boards, including the [[Mayo Foundation]], [[Chase Manhattan Bank]], [[Johnson & Johnson]], and [[Metropolitan Life Insurance]]. Ganz Cooney recognized that she was invited to serve on these boards because she was a woman, and because companies were trying to be more inclusive. She also did some public speaking on the behalf of the CTW and returning to her roots, worked on documentaries. She credited her involvement with the boards with teaching her how to run an organization and about the business world. In 1990, she was the first female nonperformer to be inducted into the [[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] Hall of Fame, and was given the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] by President [[Bill Clinton]] in 1995. In 2007, Sesame Workshop founded [[The Joan Ganz Cooney Center]], an independent, non-profit organization which studies how to improve children's literacy by using and developing digital technologies "grounded in detailed educational curriculum", just as was done during the development of ''Sesame Street''. In 2014, [[Public Prep]] launched a full day pre-kindergarten program for low-income 4 year olds living in South Bronx [[New York City Housing Authority|NYC Housing Authority]] projects, called the Joan Ganz Cooney Early Learning Program.{{cite news|last=Sahm|first=Charles|title=De Blasio should endorse pre-K at charter schools|url=https://nypost.com/2014/03/25/de-blasio-needs-to-extend-olive-branch-in-charter-school-war/|accessdate=May 31, 2014|newspaper=NY Post|date=May 25, 2014|location=New York NY}} ==Honors== ''Unless otherwise stated, the items in this list are from [http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=cooneyjoan The Museum of Broadcast Communications].'' {{div-col}} * National Institute for Social Sciences Gold Medal, 1971 * [[Frederick Douglass]] Award, New York [[Urban League]], 1972 * Silver Satellite Award, American Women in Radio and TV, 1979 * Woman of the Decade Award, 1979 * [[National Endowment for the Arts]], Friends of Education Award, 1981 * [[Kiwanis]] Decency Award, 1981 * [[National Association of Educational Broadcasters]] Distinguished Service Award, 1981 * [[Stephen S. {{coord missing|County Meath}} The '''Knockans''' is an [[Iron Age]] [[linear earthwork]] located in south-west [[Ireland]], believed to be the site of the ancient [[Tailteann Games (ancient)|Tailteann Games]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Historical site to be restored |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/education/historical-site-to-be-restored-1.81602 |accessdate=23 November 2018 |publisher=The Irish Times |date=13 June 1997}}</ref>
One of a number of [[History_of_Ireland#Iron_Age|Irish Iron Age]] linear earthworks, the Knockans is a double-banked monument partly destroyed by bulldozer in May 1997, which saw the northern bank totally destroyed and other material damage done.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tourism plan for ancient site in Meath |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/tourism-plan-for-ancient-site-in-meath-1.87086|publisher=The Irish Times|date=2 July 1997 |accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Black Pig's Dyke]] * [[Dorsey, County Armagh]] * [[Rathduff trench]] * [[Magheracar earthwork]]
